150239475.review:
This is an extremely feel-good, slice-of-life kind of game that's very in touch with its audience. Chic and candid are probably the two best words I would use to describe it. It has that retro feel while also building its own unique identity, and it never feels like it's trying to hard or too little to be what it was designed to be. The aesthetics are perfect, the music is on point, and the story is simple, but deep. The characters are so cute and yet surprisingly compelling in ways that break many stereotypes, and not in a way that feels deliberately edgy or "against the grain". They're just—honest. The only part that disappointed me was that there wasn't MORE, but that's hardly a bad thing. 

So if you're looking for a game to wind down and leave you with that feel-good vibe, this is your gem.

150147296.review:
VA-11 Hall-A is the visual novel that got me into visual novels. In fact, it's the visual novel that got me into chill, linear, bar-tending visual novels (which is a genre with multiple entries, believe it or not).

The story is a small and is about a cool, melancholy bartender and her friends and customers. It's not an epic tale. It's set against the backdrop of a cyberpunk dystopia, but this context serves primarily to augment the story and presentation without overpowering it.

If you want a bigger story, in both scope and scale, check out 2064: Read Only Memories -- it's set in the same universe and makes an excellent companion piece to this game. If, however, you're in the mood to relax and enjoy a cozy, heartfelt, deeply interpersonal story, then this is it.

it's like, bad.

i love the dystopian genre. but i cannot find a single redeeming quality about this game, honestly. the exposition ["a feudal society controlled with nanomachines"] is haunting and realistic. after that exposition tho it was bunk. 

the characters are projecting this terribly written monologue at the idle bartender. it is immersion breaking, it feels like the devs are literally trying to impress their belief complex upon me. "hurr durr media corruption i am reporter i like money". i mean first of all this is fu*king stupid: we are playing a VIDEO game, if you have something to say - SHOW it.   i don't want to literally flip through 200 prompts. second of all it is crudely drafted. it feels like not only are the devs trying to force their beliefs on me, they do it with juvenile, messy way.

the dialogue [which comprises 100% of the experience] fu*king blows. in a totalitarian future an oppressed population are evidently sliding around getting laid. every other line is a smut one-liner. somehow despite the humor in this game being only 7 years old it feels more tired than the dialogue in the original Fallout. it is painfully outmoded. Fallout's creators said they wanted jokes to be funny even if the player never enjoyed the reference - the experience is made timeless. in this game almost all dialogue can only be interpreted through the lens of a mid 2010 person. none of it feels grounded in a fictional universe. the world of VA-11 Hall-A might as well not exist.

the actual bartending is... what? i just don't even understand why this would be included. it's literally the depth of cookie clicker. you press colored buttons in certain amounts, then "serve". where is the fun? i am legitimately bewildered

for every 10 words in dialogue they could easily be concatenated into 5. it's verbose, too. it wastes everyone's time. the dialogue is not thought provoking, it is not funny, it is not even creative, it's bad. it might be dredged up from a digital archive in 2453 AD and studied as being "a product of its time" - sorta like that ET game that was recently excavated from a landfill in New Mexico. that will be its only function.

146199419.review:
I've had this game for ages and finally finished it. It's a simple game, more like a visual novel, the only way you can mess up is incorrectly mixing the drinks. Often it's very clear what to do, sometimes you need to refer back to a hint you find in the game or a character may have mentioned their favorite drink in a previous visit. The story is interesting and the atmosphere is great, but I'm not sure I like the style. I love the character developments, but I felt like there wasn't much going on. A few heavy subjects are handled, and well, but it reminded me of reading a novel versus a short story. The endings are relatively ambiguous as to the MC's future and you don't get a full picture of everyone's story, mainly hints and it's best to play the game all in one. I came back a year after just playing 2-3 days in-game and was lost, but managed to finish easily enough without restarting  although some jokes/drink requests went over my head. I was a bit frustrated with the endings, I tend to prefer a longer ending in games - even if the journey is great, I prefer endings to go out with a bang. I only played once, and actually got the bad ending but felt like just finishing the game (there are two huge bills near the end, so save up or you won't make it). The bad ending wasn't so rough, and honestly I just watched the others online and am glad I didn't replay for hours to see the others. All in all, it's a good story, possibly a replay if you really love it as it's not too long, but I probably won't replay it again - at least not for a very long time. While looking up a question I had in the game I found out there is supposed to be a sequel coming out - but that was about 3 years ago so I'm not sure what happened. I'd recommend this for someone looking for something that is cyberpunk, visual novel with frequent sexual/vulgar discussions, and simple gaming, on sale. I would not buy it full price or if you have other games that interest you first. It's not a bad game, but I did have some issues - as the spoiler below notes.


***SPOILER/LOLITA SITUATION***
One reason I wouldn't buy this game if I knew what I do now. Now, I don't remember if I knew this in the beginning of the game before I took a long break and maybe it's why I stopped playing, but when I started playing again I thought a character in the game called Dorothy was a youthful looking sexbot, maybe 20ish or so who dressed in a maid costume. It is spelled out eventually that her character is "built" like a 10-13 year old, but has the mind of a 24 year old. I imagine her backstory is meant to make people uncomfortable and think about the subject. I almost stopped playing there because I didn't know if it was meant to be social commentary or more. It was really disturbing to read that.

145422603.review:
Not offline mode has ruined my play time tracker on this, real play time was something like 10-15 hours.

Valhalla really just hit me years after the fact as a delightful example of small stories in life. Time and time again its warm story telling meshed with a coldly realistic taste for the setting surprised me. Its the only game Ive ever played to accurately create the feeling you get when you become kinda fond of people you see at work all the time who you kinda on paper hate even characters like Donevan who is an absolute scummy bastard managed to foster some realistic fondness just from associations.  

Characters like the sex worker Dorothy made me so emotional, her dropping work just to be with you during the worst night of the game. Or the simple power of the little bonds you can make. The realism of what being a bartender a small small ant to the bigger world and how all you meaningfully do is connect to others. Sure powerful movers and shakers are doing stuff around you, but you cant really handle that. Best you can do is show empathy, and build friendships.

it also often just surprised me with what it wasn't doing. You never "get the girl" characters like the Idol I initially thought would sweep me off my feet and fall in love whatever like a vn simply became a friend. She has her own life, a producer boyfriend, but you listened and you cared and made a friend out of it. No more complicated than that.

It is a slight bruise on this game that with how strong and realistic a lot of the writing is, some of the writing when the game decides its time for comedy just doesn't work. The dogs are... never funny. And most tone shattering is the jokes about Sexual Assault. Which isn't inherently bad but like the setting makes it clear that the threat of sexual violence is a genuine, and real threat that every woman in the game has to be cautious off, which is a bold thing to take i love little things like that Dorothy is armed for that reason and despite being a robot refuses to be "disassembled" with any of her clients for safety, but often, more often than the threat is talked about in genuine ways its used as a silly like joke issue? 

It just strikes as tone shatteringly unrealistic from how well the characters concerns and internality are considered in conversations. 

However this issue is never an overplayed hand and while some jokes fail to land, like I don't really get anything out of one of the dogs being a big boss reference, most of the value here, is in the empathy the story shows. Both in Jill the lead who gets to be expressive and full of character, and in the people you meet especially regulars like Alma and Dorothy. Over all the hype the game had earned is delightful.

Also the music and visuals fuck.

144513210.review: VA-11 Hall-A, a game that stole my heart, a game that made me reflect on my own life and some things i have done in my own past. The gameplay of mixing drinks with funky and funny names, like the gut punch or Blue fairy and many many others will forever be stuck in my head, the wonderful art style of the characters briming with life and just, perfectly representing them like Alma's design or Jill's own design, the writing that is done with such care and attention that i will remember for long long time, characters like Dorothym Alma, Jill, Virigillo, Sei, Jill, Dana and Gil, just carry a very important message about life and how it sometimes plays out, and what sometimes can be the best teacher is learning on your own mistakes and moving foward with your own life and improving yourself even if the odds you sometimes bring against yourself are against you, and the friends that you help and keep close to yourself, and trying your best to make sure they are safe and sound. Mixing drinks, decorating your room, discovering little funny refrences and secrets the game has to offer blew me away, for an indie game to juggle all these things at once and do everything at such a professional level is something i am very grateful off and amazed by, its like this game has a heart of its own, all the characters and the stories in the game brim with life and personaly experiences for us to hear out and take a giggle or consideration on. The lore of the game and the history of what happend for things to turn this way is also very great. And one of my most beloved aspects of the game is the music, few songs like "Unemoto" or "will you remember me?" made me feel a lot of emotions, the whole feature of the musicbox in the game really was a great idea. The soundtrack is amazing, every piece of the music is very well done and i find myself listening to it from time to time on spotify. The game at first may seem like a very silly goofy game but the more you look you see more and more of the games heart and the emotions it makes you feel, i personally related to characters like Jill or Dana. In conclusion, this game is a masterpiece of amazing work done by the people that worked by this game, and its one of my favorite games that i have played ever.

Very fun visual novel game :)

I originally started playing Va-ll Hall-a thinking it was going to be similar to Coffee Talk and it was in some ways, but it was mostly different in other ways. Even though both games kinda had the same gimmik, both of the games feel really different and unique from each other. Even though both games were fairly different from each other, Va-ll Hall-a still fulfilled my needs of playing a game similar to Coffee Talk so I'm a happy camper :)

For a game that is set in the future it is really down to earth and relatable in many ways. The world building was interesting and fun to learn about when reading through the in game forums and the augmented eye. Of course when it come to the cast of characters, it's really fun watching Jill interact with all of them, I especially loved her interactions with Alma. Even though the games talks about lewd things from time to time, the game is surprisingly very wholesome. To top it all off, the ost is a banger (even though I just played the same handful of songs for most of the game), I should probably add some of the songs to my spotify playlist now that I think about it. My only problem with the game is that I wish there was more content in the game, but that's mainly just a personal preference.

In conclusion, game good, if you're looking for a chill and funny visual novel game to play, play this one.


Also it has a Yuru Yuri reference which is cool too.

This most certainly isn't a game for everyone. The gameplay basically boils down to Simon says for mixing drinks. However, there's something special about hearing bar patrons vent about the problems going on in their lives. It's wholesome and relatable. The world building going on in the mega corporation dystopia that exists in this game is also fascinating.

It's funny though, the protagonist Jill, being the 'tsundere' archetype, would be a character I wouldn't enjoy in another context. Here though, it works! She has very justified reasons for brooding. Oh what silly things love can do to people! Her clientele is also full of exotic, slighty unhinged characters who are so endearing. And biZarRe. You can't help but root for them and serve up a double on the house!

This game will be a treat for you if you like visual novel/narrative focused games. My only complaint is that I want to know more about Dana Zane the Red Comet and her crazy life.

143615006.review:
**VA-11 Hall-A RATING (No spoilers) **

Story - 6/10
Art - 7/10
Characters - 9/10
Character Development for Jill Stingray - 7/10
World building - 6.5/10
Soundtrack - 6/10
Main story gameplay - 5/10
Enjoyment - 7/10
Overall - 7.5/10

Would highly recommend to most people to play it. The story is a pretty generic breakup romance story. However, the characters are the main reason as to explore the world of Va11halla further despite the boring gameplay mechanics. This is due to the fact that each of the characters have unique perspectives, eccentric personalities and they provide interesting insights to attempt and convey a different side and aspect of life in Glitch City. Unfortunately, the world building is only limited to the setting of the bar. The inaccessibility to explore the outside world bogs down the overall immersion and experience of Glitch City, where only glimpses of the exciting nightlife are shown. It is further hindered by the story-telling and gameplay mechanics where it's visual-novel esque style enclose makes the entire setting claustrophobic at times. The art is visually appealing and the soundtrack is decent as a whole, giving VA-11 Hall-A a total score of 7.5/10.

143479975.review:
VA-11 Hall-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action is a truly special game.

More than any other game I've played, VA-11 Hall-A makes you feel for the characters. Every character in this game is incredibly complex and compelling. You end up wanting to learn as much as you can about each and every one of them. Which, in a way, is the whole point of the game.

Your goal, as the motto says, is to mix drinks and change lives. It's an incredibly engaging way to go about gameplay. The story and characters aren't influenced by your direct actions. Instead, the story develops based solely on what drinks you serve. Its a unique and innovative approach to storytelling that really draws you in, encouraging you to learn what drinks each character would like so that you can get a better ending.

The music is also great. It really sets the vibe of the bar and the cyberpunk setting.

Overall Score: 10/10

Positive points
- Characters
- Setting
- Storylines
- Music

Negative points
- Literally None

141587536.review:
“VA-11 Hall-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action”, simply shortened to “Valhalla” is a dystopian, cyberpunk visual novel with an aesthetic heavily steeped in Anime, developed by Sukeban Games and published by Ysbryd Games and AGM Playism on 21.06.2016. In it, you take on the role of Jill Stingray, in media res, as she wakes up to another day, just like any other day. She lives in Glitch City, a place overrun with a horrible economy, terrible political management, fake and shock news, which keeps on repeating the same stories, a corrupt police body called “The White Knights” (evoking either the image of something pristine, or something pretentious, as well as putting in mind the word “cleansing”) and other horrors, which hide unfortunate murmurs of our real world within. Her bar, VA-11 Hall-A, is like a second home. Truthfully, it may be the last one she has, as she fills her dreary nights with the company of her strange, colorful coworkers and an even more eccentric and blooming cast of patrons.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
[h1]PRO[/h1]
+ An incredible soundtrack, which you unlock more and more of overtime, and which can be freely configured (playlist-style) to your liking, in the bars jukebox
+ An immense cast of characters, each with incredible designs, backstories and personalities
+ Some of the greatest video game writing to have ever been put on display
+ Impeccable displays of humor and lightheartedness, amidst the bleakness of the presented world
+ Really fun, and simple bartending gameplay
+ Beautiful graphics
+ Multiple endings
+ Extra content, crossovers and easter eggs
+ QoL: dialogue skipping (ctrl), looking back on previous dialogue you accidentally skipped (tab)

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
> Pretty long, took me about 16.5 hours to complete, according to Steam (some of that was extra content and leaving the game running by accident though)

[h1]CON[/h1]
- Some minor language mistakes from time to time
- I would’ve loved to have gotten to learn a little bit more about some of the characters, though their unresolved enigma might be on purpose

[h1]Review[/h1]
The door opens… the little bell at the head of the entrance chimes to signal another patron's approach. Soon a face appears in front of you. It’s always a surprise, you’re never quite sure whether you’ll meet a new face, a longtime regular, a friend even? The possibilities are endless, and Jill seems to agree. The job provides her some freedom; the patrons provide entertainment or enthralling stories to pass the time. They also provide mirrors and catalysts for Julianne Stingray to open herself up to both her patrons, her coworkers, and the player by proxy.
Some of these patrons will come once. Sometimes it will leave you sad, waiting for your favorite one-off patron to return, before the inevitable deflation of the credits slow, somber and yet beautifully sobering crawl. Sometimes you’ll dread a patron showing up, for fear of ruining your flawless service bonus and/or pushing your buttons, after just trying to relax on a rough day. Some of the characters hide beautiful rich worlds, that you’ll never fully know, because of their limited appearances. Some of them hide nothing, but vacuity and you’ll see them plenty more than you’d like. And yet all of them will surprise you. Thus is the power of VA-11 Hall-A.
The sparse gameplay elements: The bartending, the buying of items for Jill to not get distracted the next day, the clicking through forums and newspapers in your room before work, as well as a minigame, all serve to breakup some of the reading and get you back into focus, as well as to remind you of your presence in this world, of your agency as the player having consequences, on your voyeurism into these turbulent lives being real, the game’s inherent virtual nature aside. The future it presents, like most of the shining examples of science fiction, is plausible, and it’s that plausibility, which lends even more of a sting to the game’s visceral themes and presentation, like just enough seasoning to an already remarkable dish.
It, admittedly, took me long, for various reasons, to get through this whole game. I took it at my own pace, much like everyone takes life at their own pace, insofar as they’re given the chance to. And yet, every time the title screen flashed on, I was excited to crawl back into this rundown city, into that cozy little microcosm, hidden in one of its somewhat subterranean recesses. I worried for the characters. I laughed with them. I cried with them. And I sure as hell felt their victories.
VA-11 Hall-A isn’t a melancholic story. It’s not a happy story either. It’s not a comedy or a drama. It’s all of them. In fact, VA-11 Hall-A might be one of the most human stories to be put to screen and keyboard, despite its Anime stylings, and many of its characters being not human at all… at least not in the biological sense.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Sometimes a gem drops into your lap. Sometimes you miss an indie release with a pretty substantial following such as this, for a long time. As I had done for years. It is, however, my sincerest pleasure to have been privy to the incredible, bespoke art of VA-11 Hall-A’s skilled creators. This is an unforgettable experience, and one I’m sure to come back to somewhere in my life. It turns out Julianne’s mirrors, the windows into her patron’s souls, staring back at her like the Nietzschean abyss, also reflected right back at me through her eyes, and may prove a catalyst for me, all the same.

[h3]Thank You To Sukeban Games, Ysbryd Games And AGM Playism For Blessing Us With This Work Of Art For The Ages.[/h3]

141423823.review:
[b] [u] LIGHT SPOILERS FOR THIS REVIEW! Just warning you know just in case you care. [/u] [/b]

Well, well, well...been a bit since I've wrote a review, but I'm back and now full of VA-11 Hall-A (like, literally everything I could get my hands on.) So, without further, let's mix drinks and start this review.

[h1] VA-11 Hall-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action [/h1]


[h1] [u] The Story [/u] [/h1]

While everyone in this game in a way has their own stories that get touched upon as you progress through the game. The main story with our protagonist Jill is overall a pretty nicely-paced, emotionally investing, and really solid story that covers relationships, death and how people deal with it, and what it means to be human and learning how to express one's feelings. While I'm simply outlining the themes, once you play it, you'll definitely see these themes (among a lot more) come into play. The multiple narratives with every character and how Jill's own story ties into theirs and hers is really neat and definitely is a highlight of the game.

[h1] [u] The Gameplay [/u] [/h1]

VA-11 Hall-A's gameplay is so iconic in my opinion and yet it's soooo...simple. I guess that's what it so iconic, it's fun, simple, yet still offers up a nice challenge for things to not get boring. It's simple enough, a customer ask for a drink, you get the right number of ingredients for the respective drink and you either mix or blend it. What's interesting is things like where you need to [i] double [/i] the ingredients for drinks sometimes and while quite a few drinks that simply need to be mixed, there are a few that need to be blended, thus you have to mix them longer for them to come out properly. It's little spices in the combinations of mixed or blending and the number of ingredients that make it so fun to mix drinks, really makes you feel like a professional drink mixer. There's also things to factor in like which drink does a customer wants and the fact that you can sometimes give customers different drinks that still satisfy them, the secret drinks that net you bonus dialogue and other potential endings (cause yeah, this game has a few of them) that also add to the game, giving replay value and even [i] more [/i] complexity to the gameplay. Definitely one of the many reasons why I love this game so much.

[h1] [u] The Characters [/u] [/h1]

Aaaand here's one of my [i] absolute favorite [/i] parts about this game. All varied, quirky, nicely-designed, lovable (and therefore marketable, google VA-11 Hall-A Plushes for more info), and well-written. I won't go into how they all work, but all of them have charm and a lot more depth than you'd think upon first glance. While some characters have their own endings and others don't, it doesn't make the ones who don't have one any less interesting because the game does a good job over its run time fleshing out and developing a lot of the characters to where we get to see them at their highs and lows. For a game so simple and with admittedly obvious limitations, it goes above and beyond giving its characters the time of day to make a lot of them memorable and likable. I won't pick any favorites, but I have a select few who I personally love more than others, but again, I like the entire cast. Another game that's so good with its characters that I love them all is always a good thing.

[h1] [u] The Sound Design [/u] [/h1]

This section will sadly be brief, as there's not much to say in terms of sound design outside of the music. In fact, there aren't really any sounds effects outside the dialogue boxes and their scrolling text sounds and some bar noises (which granted are perfectly fine), so let's get to that music!

The music, in short, for being composed all by one person (you're the goat, Garoad!) is [i] outstanding! [/i]  It's a surprisingly large soundtrack (if we account for the different releases of albums as well) and it's all really well-composed and has a lot of variety to it. Rock, Ambient, Breakcore, Chill, Noir, it's all really good stuff, so good that it's yet another game soundtrack I've listened to songs from outside of the game! Aaahh...being a nut for music is a blessing and a curse, I suppose. A++ stuff, truly. Getting to pick what songs you like from the jukebox gets extra brownie points cause I liked spicing up each day with more and more songs I hadn't listened to yet.

[h1] [u] The Verdict [/u] [/h1]

VA-11 Hall-A, in short is an absolutely amazing game, especially for being an indie game. It's got a great story with a lovable cast of characters, good music, absolutely great writing with both its emotional moments and its casual banter and comedy alike and it totally had won me over within the first couple hours of playing...I think my hours and the fact I've 100%'ed it should be an indication with how much I loved it and with that preface I said before all of this. I wholeheartedly recommend this game and it'd be a 10/10 for me given how much it hits all of the right places for me...also one of the people who worked on is a SUDA51 fan, so that uhh...yeah, that might be influencing me a little bit, heh.

Go mix some drinks and change those lives! I'm off to play some Like a Dragon: Ishin! and Tsukihime...and probably a lot of Street Fighter 6 cause [i] good GOD [/i] is that game so good. Comments are allowed as always for those who wanna talk about the games I review with me.

141337258.review:
VA-11 Hall-A is a pretty simple visual novel with a tiny faux-drink mixing mini-game attached. The mechanics aren't a big focus, the story is front and center. You play as Jill the bartender in a 2070's dystopian hole in the wall bar, with tons of anime and scifi references and call-outs. 

The game is an homage to early japanese PC games, complete with a scanlines option. To me, VA-11 Hall-A felt a lot like a nintendo DS game, with bright colors, a simple but mechanically weird game system, and the chiptune-y OST.

The game is good, and quite well written. Characters gain depth as they visit the bar and slowly become regulars, and if you do well you slowly learn more about them. A big theme in VA-11 Hall-A is the expectations put on to us by others and ones we hold over ourselves, and by the end of my playthrough I have thoroughly enjoyed myself. It's well worth finishing, though completionists should be aware the game features a short, but brutal bullet-hell mini-game to 100% all the achievements.

140789569.review:
This game should not be tagged as "sim" or "life sim". It's purely a visual novel.

The art is incredible and the best part about the game.

The main theme of the game is about overcoming grief with the support of our loved ones. Also, a reminder that life is short and to live without regrets. The story also brought up some interesting sci-fi predictions for the future of the human race, such as people surrounding themselves purely with AI companions, however, the predictions never went deeper than "wouldn't it be funny if..."

At the end of the day, for me, the execution of the story was bland. Each of the numerous sideplots of the minor characters never had much of a defined arch and felt about as dull as reading about someone's shitty situation on /r/advice with no clear conclusion. Overall, story felt half-baked, with little sense of interconnection between all the characters, and it felt as though the game relied on the skin of its art to appeal to the player. The characters were at the mercy of the world around them, and simply came to the bar to complain about it instead of doing anything to change the world outside.

139621823.review:
VA-11 Hall-A is a game that I had already given some consideration to before receiving it as a recommendation. I’m a fan of visual novels, and I have a few friends that like it, so at some point I considered playing. However, due to it being a iyashikei, I can’t say I would’ve ever played considering my taste has fluctuated a lot towards action heavy stories, and there are many other visual novels I’d rather read. TSince someone gave me the game though, I was able to have one of the best experiences I’ve had with the visual novel medium.

This game is soothing. Very soothing. The past few weeks have been an absolute mess in my life, a lot of stuff piled up for college and work and I had little to no free time, and the free time I did have, I invested in VA-11 Hall-A, and that might as well be the very reason I didn’t get very stressed despite my environment. The atmospherization of this game is amazing, everything is so calm but at the same time fun and interesting. Every single session that I had playing this game took away any irritation or stress I had built up previous to it. I love how simple the game and its story is, but at the same time how captivating it manages to be.

The idea of a bartender, who listens to other people’s stories, never knowing how they unfolded or how they ended unless the customer themselves says it, is an absolutely amazing concept. Everyone carries a different story within themselves, different experiences, emotions, etc. And we can’t possibly know everything about everyone, so instead we are left to know what they want us to know: this creates relationship dynamics that start very superficial, but as characters open up, they become deeper and deeper, and you start liking each character more and more. I love how this concept works, because it always kept me intrigued wondering where things would go, how was everyone doing and when would they come back to tell me the conclusion of their personal stories. Each person that comes to the bar is a genuine and unique person, each with their own quirks and set of problems, and following along their journey on the sidelines, knowing only tidbits of what they went through, that connects you to characters a lot. 

VA-11 Hall-A characters are amazingly human characters in a cyberpunk dystopia. Each person feels very refreshing and has something relatable about them, something you can empathize and even see yourself into. Even if the character is a world renowned big titty hacker, I can empathize a lot with her feelings for her family. Even if the character is a privileged aristocrat that grew up with barely any hardships in life, I appreciate a lot how open minded they can be. Alma and Stella are just some of the characters that have very absurd backgrounds, but at the same time show very human emotions, thoughts and actions. And this is something recurrent in the story, everyone you come across has some crazy ass background, but at the same time very human traits, which makes the whole story feel genuine and natural. You find yourself relating to these characters or empathizing with them, and as you hear their problems, you start rooting for them and wishing they show up again as soon as possible to know if their story went well or not. I really love the genuineness of the story.

But while I can talk about the characters that come to the bar and their own stories, at the same time the MC, Jill, has her own problems, quirks and feelings too, and that’s where I think VA-11 Hall-A shines the best. The story wouldn’t hold itself together if all that happened was you hearing snippets of stories from strangers, but having the story being told through the eyes of a genuine human who you can connect to both in flesh and feelings, makes the whole thing more engrossing. Jill is just a plain woman, with normal human-link thoughts, emotions and actions. Seeing everything unfold through her eyes, and seeing her react to everyone around her makes you feel like you’re a friend of hers, and the both of you are managing the bar. And this is even before I get started on her own personal problems, which are honestly some of the most heart touching things I’ve read recently. In comparison to some characters, Jill’s problems are really mundane. But through our eyes, seeing the gentle, compassionate and quirky bartender run away from the reality of her problems, regret past decisions and try little by little to move on makes for one of the most captivating stories in the game. Jill’s problems are not exactly something everyone has experienced, but they’re certainly something everyone is scared of experiencing and hits very close to home. Everyone is scared of fighting and breaking apart with a loved one (be it a lover or someone else) and only hearing news after said loved one dies. Jill’s problems represent an universal fear of every human, and seeing how those problems drag her down after seeing her cheerful persona tugs the strings of any reader’s heart. I wanted Jill to be happy so badly, I didn’t want to see her suffer the death of Lenore, I wanted to be there by her side comforting her, telling everything would be okay. At the same time, seeing her go through all of that reinforced in the back of my mind the idea that I wouldn’t want that to happen to me, and that created a connection so strong between us that I suffered with her, and in the end, I smiled with her reconciliation with Lenore’s sister. Jill is a bonafide human confined by the chains of a virtual game, and I appreciate her a LOT. 

Of course, I also need to mention the amazing soundtrack. The way it lets you set the atmosphere for the day is awesome, and I really appreciate it. There is a very good mixture between calm and faster songs, and trying them all was part of the experience until I settled on a playlist I could say I enjoyed. If I have one complaint about this game, it’s just that it doesn’t let me randomize playlists automatically picking songs for me, but I didn’t really mind trying them all manually either.

A quick mention to the artstyle: it’s amazing and brimming with soul, it expresses characters and their quirknesses perfectly.

VA-11 Hall-A is not something I would’ve played by myself. I knew the game, I had shown interest in it another time, but as I am now I would’ve never given it a chance. So I’m very, very glad my friend gave me this game, and after playing through it I can say I’ll stop being so prejudiced against the iyashikei genre, I can see how good for the soul it can be now, and I’ll definitely be more open to trying similar stuff.

VA-11 Hall-A gave me a fictional world, with fictional but very human characters, and I couldn’t be happier about it. VA-11 Hall-A is a life lesson, and one I fully pretend to carry on with me throughout my own life.

139262596.review:
If you're craving for a lively near-future of a cybernetic society full of action surrounding a cyberpunk bartender, who plays a key-role as an information dealer and evil mastermind who serves shady drinks to psychologically manipulate the clients in order to satisfy her needs to set the world on fire and chaos, you 'll get disappointed here. 

Actually you'll get the opposite although I could wish for the same but what the game offered, was worth the try at the very least I assume.

Well, long story short, this isn't a game for everybody and not the type I would causally play myself. If you're a fan of slice-of-life anime series then you'd probably like this visual novel as well. The game depicts life-twists of a young and nerdy girl named Jill (an INTP) , who acts more like a listener throughout the game rather than a game-changer. (Her only goal is to survive in lower classes of a hierarchial system with a corrupted government and law enforcement department) Therefore, expect a completely passive presence of the main character who serves drinks and tries to be as flawless as she can by soothing the chaotic situations of clients. The cool part of the story is in fact represented by the clients themselves and their various personalities. (Which some of'em won't get to a conclusion at the end and as I've read in other comments the continuation is sadly on hiatus.)

My favorite character is the lovely Dorothy Haze (ENFP) and I love how energetic, cheerful and insightful she was. So her presence kinda compensated the lack of great cliffhangers through the story for me and the boredom the main character caused me to experience ! No offense to Jill lovers out there tho!

My view on soundtracks is neutral. There is nothing cool 'bout it to mention, unfortunately. I had to skip some of'em from jukebox cause they clashed paradoxically with supposedly chill and easy atmosphere of the game.

Overall I'll give this game a 7 outta 10 and I recommend it to anyone who likes a boring character's dramatic background! Take it as a sarcasm or not. Up to you!

139245474.review:
Jill is a bartender at VA-11 HALL-A, more affectionately known as Valhalla; a small and somewhat classy bar located in one of the safer downtown areas of Glitch City. Between mixing drinks, occasionally bullying your weird but friendly coworker Gillian, figuring out which of the multitude of fantastical rumors about your boss are true, and saving up for rent, life is pretty chill. The same can’t be said for your regulars, unfortunately. Crime and violence in the city has always been high, and as the barkeep, you get to hear all the juicy and gruesome details. Time to mix drinks and change lives! 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2974954415 
11-18 hours to complete, VA-11 HALL-A is a dystopian cyberpunk bartending simulator that is honestly, pretty impressive. Well written with plenty of story and secrets, the NPC’s had actual substance and the world building is immersive and thorough. I’m not sure what the word count on this interactive VN is, but I seriously doubt it’s under 100,000. The bartending and making drinks aspect was a bit intimidating at first, but it’s actually super simple once you realize – there is a book you can pull up at any time that lists (almost) all the drinks and what you need to make them and at no point in the game are you on a timer. Without spoiling, If literally any of this sounds appealing to you, I’d straight up recommend just playing it, I had a great time and looking at other reviews, a ton of other people did too. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2975018333

138384385.review:
I like this game. I like it a lot.

Is it perfect? Naw. I could do with a solid 10% less horniness to the whole thing, and there are certainly characters who I enjoy a lot less than others, and—as is endemic to visual novels without any actual dialogue choices—the player interactivity is quite low. But, let's meet the game where it is.

VA-11 Hall-A is a story about a harsh world, filled to the brim with people—generally working class—living out their lives in a cyberpunk setting where a corporation basically owns the entire city, and rent keeps going up. They are, however, ultimately still living their lives. They have their own problems, their own lives, their own solutions, and ultimately, they feel real in an almost intangible way. It's hard for a world to make its cast feel real, but this accomplishes that (at least imo).

It's also a nerdy story which throws in jokes in every corner of the game, literally the first news story you can read—one of the first things that players will see—is a not-at-all subtle reference to Metal Gear Rising. There's a protracted sequence in the game where Y11K cosplayers show up and make reference to "The Greatest Game Of All Time" (their words not mine).

It is both of the above games, and I like them both. The game feels like it is often bouncing back and forth between lighthearted discussions of nothing inparticular with the occasional nerdy reference thrown in, and a serious, sincere story about the kinds of problems people are having now just as much as they're having 50 years in the future. It's an odd kind of comforting to see modern problems reflected 50 years into the future, because it naturally implies that we won't be so fucked 50 years in the future that stuff like family troubles, relationship drama, rent going up, and the general worry of trash bosses will still be normal, still be real.

It's a very *me* game, is what I'm trying to say. It's nerdy in the way I'm nerdy. It's serious and sincere in the ways I like reading about. If you like those kinds of stories, then I'd highly recommend this visual novel.

137517256.review:
Warhammer es un juego de guerra de miniaturas de mesa que fue creado por Games Workshop en 1983. El juego se desarrolla en un mundo de fantasía oscuro y violento en el que los jugadores controlan ejércitos de figuras en miniatura que representan guerreros, magos y monstruos.

Hay dos configuraciones principales en el universo de Warhammer: Warhammer Fantasy Battle y Warhammer 40,000. Warhammer Fantasy Battle está ambientado en un mundo de fantasía medieval lleno de magia, dragones y épicas batallas entre ejércitos de humanos, elfos, enanos y otras razas. Warhammer 40,000 está ambientado en el futuro lejano y presenta tecnología avanzada, poderosos marines espaciales y hordas de razas alienígenas que luchan por el control de la galaxia.

En ambas configuraciones, los jugadores construyen y pintan ejércitos en miniatura, y luego los usan para luchar entre sí en un campo de batalla de mesa. El juego se juega usando dados para determinar los resultados de las acciones y estrategias.

Con el tiempo, Warhammer se ha convertido en una franquicia masiva con una amplia gama de productos, incluidos videojuegos, novelas e incluso una película de acción en vivo en desarrollo. El juego tiene una base de fans dedicada que disfruta de la inmersión en el mundo y la jugabilidad estratégica que Warhammer ofrece.

136852607.review:
I loved how much each character felt like they had actual personalities, and you can tell the creators put effort into making them unique. It was fun watching them grow, and how Jill grew over time as well.
Most of the patrons were one-on-one conversations with Jill. But the moments when you realise a character is talking about another and revealing backstory you could only get from a 3rd party's perspective was a really nice touch that makes you go "Oooohhhh" when you realise it. 

The only downside I can think of is that following a guide is essential if you want to get all the good character endings. Some of the drinks you need to purchase in advance and you'd have no way of knowing that until it's too late. Another drink exists that you literally could not know about without sitting there endlessly trying all drink permutations.

Minor gripe though. The game was very enjoyable, and I definitely recommend. I received it in a Humble Bundle, but it's worth full price.

136307148.review:
I heard about this game ages ago and how well received it was, but it wasn't until I heard some of the music that I actually became interested. Almost wasn't going to play it, but I gave it a shot and I loved every moment of it. From the atmosphere, the characters and their stories, the music of course, every single part of this game made me feel nostalgic as if I had already played it 20 years ago as a kid and came back to relive a fond memory. Jill and her friends are so well and realistically written (for the vast majority of the game, mind you. There's some weebyness to it too) that it wasn't hard at all for all of them to grow on me and feel as if they were my friends too. 

To conclude my review, I'll semi-quote Jill on a sentiment that closely resembles my own in how I approach strangers and friends in life. Everyone has a story to tell, and I just really like listening to people tell them. This is a game about strangers, friends, and family telling their stories who live in a world that in many ways resembles our own. It's heartfelt, silly, and at times suspenseful and a little sad. But it's a story worth being told, worth listening to, and worth thinking on long after you're done in the hopes that it may affect your own personal growth as it does for the cast of VA-11 Hall-A.

Overall Score:

Game Pros
• Highly Addicting

• Split Screen Multiplayer

• Diversity in game modes
• Controller support (The game suggests to use a controller, but honestly, the keyboard works perfectly. All preference)

Game Cons
• Bought by Epic Games. Servers seem to have got worse. Packet loss and lag are a frequent problem for some.
• Forces cross-play to enter tournaments

Relateable Games
• Supersonic Acrobatic Rocket-Power Battle-Cars

Conclusion
Rocket League is an amazing game. You know those games that you play while you should be going to bed? That's this game. Only 90 minutes into the game, and i've already had so much fun with it. I would honestly reccomend this game to anyone. Unless you REALLY hate soccer, and you simultaneously REALLY hate cars.

135397952.review: Va-11 Hall-A tells many stories in many ways, it'll have you reading between the lines and investigating every character, excited to see the next patron who enters through those hallowed doors. You've always got company or something new to jump into, even when your shift is over you'll catch yourself reading the news or random shitposts on the internet that all connect so vividly together.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              There will be times when the dialogue hits close to home, and the world may not be real but it'll have you fooled as it carries itself so well-written through the voices of every equally well-developed and unique character who dares to catch themselves sitting across from you, Jill, asking for a drink at the end of their very possibly miserable day. Your job is to get them drunk, and the incentive to do it well is there. You have bills to pay, subscriptions to save up for, and your own worries to subside with the same consumerism everybody in Glitch City is mesmerized in by purchasing little doodads and thingamajigs at the end of the day, just to make life a little bit better. If you don't perform or manage your money well, you'll find yourself kicked outta your apartment and... Game over.                                                                                                                                                                                                                While the gameplay is simple, there are many ways it changes to keep your bar-tending expertise sharp. Some folks don't always know what they want, some are straight-forward and give the exact drink they want, and one guy even always asks for the same ol' big beer. The drinks are categorized by flavor, class, and name, so you can always find what you're looking for in the recipe book. It's pretty common to be able to choose from a wider variety of drinks, so you can often choose how much karmotrine your customers get. Karmotrine is the magic ingredient that results in how drunk they're gonna get, more equals drunker. Sometimes you'll see "optional karmotrine", so you can fix a drink with as much as it can possibly hold or as much as your willing to pour, even if that's none. Naturally, the more or less drunk the person your serving is, the ever so different the dialogue exchange becomes between Jill and whomever it is on the other side of the counter. Of course, you can even serve them a totally different drink from what they request, and they'll drink it though disappointed. The only issue is that you won't get paid for that drink, or receive your flawless service bonus. Wanna get somebody who can handle their liquor hammered? Be prepared to put the drinks on YOUR tab.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Va-11 Hall-A is an absolute gem of a game that I personally adore, everything you can think of already thought of and your answers to the deeper questions around Glitch City will usually be decipherable in due time if you're memory is solid and your curiosity peaks. The regulars around town will charm you and keep you reading, never sure what strange news they'll bring to your shoddy slice of Eden next. A strange but very believable and wonderfully developed world, down to every detail. Playing Valhalla is like reading the same page of a book over and over again, but there's always something new at the end of each page, just waiting for the paper to flip itself over.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I bought it on my switch, it's become a personal favorite and "comfort" game for me not unlike many others, and when my nerves are shot this game helps me find peace. 10/10, Jill fanboy signin' out :)

133001420.review:
A really, REALLY promising premise, great character designs, lovely style and music, and unique cute little game mechanic... completely ruined by terrible, terrible writing. It shows such amazing promise and teases you with these interesting and unique ideas... and then does... nothing. Which is worse than just being plain bad, because now I'm disappointed. 

[spoilers] There's a lot of issues, like the world building losing all depth as the game goes on, or Jill's boring and distracting plot about her ex-girlfriend. But the biggest issues with the game can be summed up with the most interesting, and most terribly executed character, Dorothy. Dorothy is a sex worker robot who is designed to look like a child. This is an incredibly taboo and messed up concept, so I was really curious and fascinated to see how the game would handle Dorothy. How does she grapple with her morals, by looking like a kid for the purpose of sex work? How do other characters feel about this, or how do they feel about the society they live in, that lets robots like Dorothy thrive? How does Dorothy deal with criminally perverse clientele? Does she ever have doubts about her clientele and the morals of catering to them? When she flirts with other characters, how to they deal with a child-shaped robot flirting? 

The answer the game gives us is... there is no answer. Dorothy doesn't exist for world building, she exists to make sexual innuendos, and every single other character simply doesn't address the elephant in the room that she has sex with paedophiles. You can hear the writer skirting around the topic of paedophilia in every bit of dialogue there is about Dorothy's profession. In a blog post I read from the devs, they talked about writing challenging characters from a messed up cyberpunk dystopia. But in execution, they're too scared to say anything beyond the most surface level anime poisoned fluff dialogue and jokes about dick. Dorothy eventually starts to make me uncomfortable, as I realise that she isn't there for anything other than to have a funny "loli" (eugh) character say sex jokes-- 'but guys, its okay, shes a robot and shes mentally in her 20s! we emphasise that so you know its okay for her to be making constant passes at you the player, and every character in the bar! this is challenging writing!' 

This encapsulates what's wrong with everything in the game. Surface level, shallow, anime-poisoned writing, hinting at dark and/ or interesting ideas but too terrified of the weight of its own ideas to commit to anything TOO unsavoury or controversial, despite having a literal child-shaped robot sex worker as a prominent main character. 

Listen to the OST but do not buy or play.

131594023.review:
Va-11 Hall-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action is great despite all the odds that are stacked against Sukeban Games and its release is a miracle. Made by a group of Venezuelans from /u/, Va-11 Hall-A is not only a tribute to their love for cyberpunk, retro Japanese PC-98 games, and yuri, but also a reflection of their life in Venezuela. You can spot many 3rd world and authoritarian regime struggle that many Venezuelans suffered in its stories that is served via its cyberpunk theme like about some guy/gal getting harassed and attacked by the military when buying groceries, extremely high prices or even shortages of everyday needs, waiting in line for hours just to get flour, or how going out at night is not safe. In Glitch City, brutality in all its forms is an everyday reality and the quality of life for the non-powerful decreases at an alarming rate and marginalization are getting wider. In Caracas, the wealth gap separates the society and, even though many marginalized communities took to the street and was benefitted from the Bolivarian Revolution during the early Chavez's regime, the whole quality of life for Venezuelans decreases at an alarming rate during the later Chavez’s regime and hits the worst low in Maduro’s. It's really sad how things turned out for Sukeban Games so much that N1RV Ann-A is even now indefinitely delayed due to their situations back home. Even moving to a greener pasture (some have moved to Japan, the US, and other) can't guarantee a success since they are still tied to Venezuela. Va-11 Hall-A was made frantically and the sweat and tears that were shed during its making definitely shows and filled Va-11 Hall-A with soul and shows how Sukeban Games gave zero fucks to their limitations.

The paragraph above only serves to show how lucky we are to have Va-11 Hall-A under the deteriorating quality of life in Venezuela and the struggle to make it, but they made it alright. Va-11 Hall-A is now widely known as that chill cyberpunk bartender visual novel, redeeming Venezuela's reputation from "that country that made Crazy Bus." It oozes Cyberpunk style, the usual trope of Cyberpunk such as neon city, police state, artificial humans, techno dystopia, and many more can be found in Va-11 Hall-A but the devs chose to focus on a more mundane setting, not a detective or runaway android but a bartender. That decision opens up a more down-to-earth themed cyberpunk story where the focus is not the world but the people. The writings and visuals of Va-11 Hall-A is amazing and was the creation of two friends, Ferfer [?] or Ironiclark (Fernando Damas) and kiririn51 (Christopher Ortiz). Both of them managed to create one of the comfiest yet engaging cyberpunk experiences and every part of the game correlates with each other, from its user interface to the dialogues, all of them really screams cyberpunk. The theme is cyberpunk, a genre that can demonize many kind of people, a genre where people always suffer, a genre that is known to be a story about dystopias, a genre that inspired from the worries of rapid industrialization, technological development, and capitalist insanity, and yet Sukeban Games manage to portray how the people stay positive from its characters and their interactions that never conform to the cyberpunk stereotypes even though they seem to follow the stereotypes on the surface.

For me the strongest part of Va-11 Hall-A’s narrative is not its story, but its characters and their interaction with the world. Ferfer [I’m not really sure what nickname to use, should it be Fernando?] managed to make a really intriguing cyberpunk experience by balancing plot and gameplay while also giving depth to the characters. I don’t know if the characters were written first by Ferfer or were designed first by kiririn51 but all of them are perfect. I won’t go into detail about the characters but the main protagonist, Jill Stingray, and her friends, colleagues, and clients are an interesting bunch with different perspectives of life and slowly we’ll see their problems and secrets. Some characters seems to be your typical cyberpunk character and some are an interesting reflection of Venezuelans or the writer’s personal experience but they don’t shove their character themes to your face since Ferfer always put somekind of depth into the character or balances things out to move away from stereotypes. The dialogue and the interactions between characters are great although it can be annoying at times but it is nice and engaging to read. Now, the gameplay experience can be underwhelming since it’s really simple. Hell, I even have a more engaging and fun experience of mixing drinks in Space Station 13 than in Va-11 Hall-A. But the bartending mechanic had to be there to enhance the experience and even though it is simple, Ferfer successfully incorporates it to the world and story, you’ll appreciate if you see the ingredients and its explanation. You’ll mix drinks and change lives, including Jill’s. The story isn’t something groundbreaking, and some might even don’t find the idea of reading it entertaining, but I was definitely invested into the story.

Again, the characters are the best part of Va-11 Hall-A and that is also because of kiririn51 character designs that are really beautiful with many defining features. Humans and their artificial limbs, the artificial humans, brain in a jar, all screams cyberpunk though with a moe twist. You could also see the retro/PC-98 VN inspired artstyle, not only in the characters but in the overall artwork and the user interface. They managed to align the art and the narrative and which shows how the final product is a labor of love, not surprising since the game design and original concept was the work of Ferfer and kiririn51. CALICOMP, Jill’s Room, DANGER/U/, and all other part of the game evokes futuristic yet cozy vibe. You’ll be in the dark for most part of the game so I’ll recommend playing it in the dark.

And then who can forget the official soundtrack which for many are the best part of the game. Garoad (Michael Kelly) crafted a very nice compilation of chill retro-synthwave inspired soundtrack and I believe he was inspired by other video game composers like Ryu Umemoto and Shoji Meguro. You are in control of choosing the songs before bartending and they will accompany you throughout Jill’s shift. I still listen to the OST from time to time after years of playing, my personal favourite is Nighttime Maneuvers and I think track 1-4 should always be combined together when listening to the soundtrack.

I really enjoyed Va-11 Hall-A and my 2nd playthrough of it was still really comfy, playing it drunk even immerses you more into Va-11 Hall-A. Grab a drink, position yourself as comfortable as possible, and turn up the volume because you are definitely in for a ride. Sukeban Games is a really small game studio comprised of a group of friends with similar interests trying to share their passion to the world and they deserve the success. If you read the credits of Va-11 Hall-A you can see how small the number of people that is involved in the making of Va-11 Hall-A. I believe they are currently in a unfavorable situation but they are still posting updates and their works. Recently Sukeban Games released a short story titled VA-11 Hall-A: Sapphic Pussy Rhapsody, be sure to check it out if you are craving for more Va-11 Hall-A content.

131144628.review:
When I was a kid, I had the habit of buying CD magazines all the time with whatever amount of money I'd manage to save. I remember this one time where there was this shareware version of a flash game called "Last Call", where you'd play the role of a bartender. The patrons were really unique, and not only you'd have to worry about mixing and serving them the right drinks, but you'd also have to be careful to check their IDs to see if they were legal or not

That said, when I looked this game available for sale, I was instantly transported back to that time. Well, at least before I actually installed and tried it, because it wasn't so hard to realize that there were many different aspects available

First of all, rather than just being a plain simulator experience, this is a cyberpunk themed visual novel, which also has a bartender mechanic, therefore adding some variety to the work. In other words, besides the standard system of simply selecting what phrases you're going to say, every now and then you also get to mix drinks for your customers. Most of the time they're straightforward about their orders, but of course, there's always an exception to that rule

The protagonist that you control also has a personality of her own, and she constantly interacts with the customers, boss and coworker listening to their ramblings and learning about their stories. In the beginning I didn't really get some things about her, but as the story moves forward things get a bit clearer. Instead of having to deal with a set number of missions to complete, the "adventure" provides a certain amount of days before the game is over. You can use the money that you receive by the end of your shifts to buy stuff to decorate your bedroom

The graphics, soundtrack and sound effects are pretty neat, as they really help to create immersion, which is definitely the mood that one could go for while playing this kind of genre. Some achievements can be missed and they can be a big annoying to get, especially if you need to start all over from scratch; my point being that despite having the option to skip the texts that you've already been through before, you still need to deal with the customer's orders. So if you're the kind of person who doesn't like to play with a guide under your nose, my advice is to finish the game once (to have the optimal experience), and then read the instructions to fill in the blanks

Overall, this game provides a nice combination of genres and I certainly recommend it to anyone who enjoys visual novels, drinking, good music and the cyberpunk style

130995357.review:
Design and visuals are really cool. Music is good. That's all there is to it, and apparently it's more than enough to please the average audience.

I really wanted to like this but it's just the most shallow slice of life you can ever think of, with cyberpunk aesthetics sprinkled on it. You hear people constantly talking about the city going to crap and you get the hints of a big incident involving the local megacorporation, but you don't see anything of it, nor it has any direct impact on the protagonist's life. They might as well have this set during the Prohibition era and nothing would've really changed. Some of the characters aren't even all bad, but they all share the same level of shallowness in their writing. They're cardboard cutouts with a bare hint of backstory - and not all of them even got it. Throughout all the game you have the feeling that something is yet to happen, but it never does, and the ending is open in the sense that things will go on more or less like before, with just some little personal realization on the protagonist's part. You know, the classical "I have to change my life somehow" stuff, albeit we don't really know how. Both anticlimatic and disappointing, to say the least.

Oh, and the protagonist sees some kind of cybernetic ghost every now and then, but it's never explained why or who she actually is. Wait for it in the sequel, I guess. But I think I'll pass, thanks.

130277563.review:
I was really on the fence about this game.

The visuals of this game are stunning. I love pixel graphics like this and the color palette of dark purples and blues contrasted with neon pinks is perfect. The effects are neat and I love the little touches like the changing TV screen and the Metal Gear codec call-style screen that comes up when you're talking to someone outside the bar. Even the drink mixing interface that you spend most of your time staring at is visually appealing. I really like the look of this one, and I cannot overstate it, because it's a huge reason as to why I got this game.

And then there's the writing.

The setting of the game is pretty clear: Glitch City is unambiguously a horrible place to live if you're not rich. This is reinforced over and over in every aspect of the game, from the corporate chokehold on the city's government, down to in-universe forum posts about standing in line for hours for milk and bread. This isn't implied, it is outright stated that Glitch City is awful to its poorest citizens.

And yet, there's a lot of wishy-washy dialogue about how corporations and class divides and the ultra wealthy aren't so bad, actually. When one character refuses to discuss classism with a rich person, they're framed as being a sore loser who just can't handle having their views challenged. When far-reaching corruption is found within a company-run police force because [i]of course it is[/i], our only interaction is through a sympathetic good cop character, who admits to having ignored the corruption because she loved her job so darn much.

It's bizarre and so jarring how this comes up again and again. And it's not a matter of clashing opinions between bar patrons, it's the way the narrative itself treats these instances, and how neutrally our financially destitute POV character interacts with the world. I can't speak to the real experiences of the devs but it feels like when someone who has never been impoverished tries to write about poverty. It just rings hollow.

That's not enough to get a negative review from me, however. Sometimes you just don't click with a game's worldbuilding. That doesn't make it a bad game, no matter how confused and at times exasperated I am with its writing.

But then came the bullet hell shmup mini-game. The one that you have to win to complete the game. Nothing, and I mean [i]nothing[/i], about modern game design makes me angrier than this. I detest this trend of sticking a mini-game into your game that's entirely different from the main game and requires an entirely different skill set and you have to beat it to 100% the game. We know who popularized it. We know what otherwise beloved game has infected the world of game design with achievement-locked, game-within-a-game bullet hells. Yeah, I'm calling you out Stardew Valley.

129751992.review:
[b]A game I wish I know it early but not so soon at the same time[/b]

At first, I play this game expecting the story to be heartwarming and sad due to the cyberpunk theme. But as I was playing the game longer and longer, the immersion starts to kick into me. Characters are more alive and have in-depth characteristics than I expected them to. I expected the whole game is telling a story, but the characters themselves are the stories of the game. And I like that a lot, most of the characters have problems that people in real life will have. About families, friends, work, society, and relationships.

When I play to the part where Jill met [spoiler]Gabby, her ex's sister. And telling Jill that her ex-girlfriend passed away due to a heart disease that worsened right after they argued. And Jill felt great guilt and was depressed about that until about the end of the game.[/spoiler] This hit me hard because I was in a similar situation as Jill, and I couldn't say anything more than I can really, really feel relatable to the character of the game. 

Thus I wish I could play this game early to know about my complexity of myself, but wish to not play it too soon or finish the game so early because I think I'm not as brave as Jill, and I still not yet have overcome this problem. But, anyway, if you want to play a chill game and maybe have some problem in your life that you are struggling with, check this game out. It can help you open your mind to a different perspective in my opinion.

129356767.review:
this game is awesome

I wish Bartenders are real

Edit: So I finally completed the game to 100%, got ALL achievements including the infamously hard Model Warrior Julianne, and I figured, fück it, time to actually make a proper review.

[h1]So... what is VA-11 Hall-A?[/h1]

Well, to put it simply, it's a Cyberpunk themed game where you play as Jill Stingray, a bartender in the BTC Certified bar coded VA-11 in the Alpha hall. Or simply, VA-11 Hall-A. You serve drinks to newcomers and regulars alike and chat with them, trade stories and perhaps discover some secrets spreading throughout the corrupt place named Glitch City.

You have 5 ingredients to make drinks out of, and you can make it aged or "on the rocks" (aka iced). Optionally, some drinks may say "Optional Kamotrine" (AKA the ingredient for alcohol) and you may choose to either keep it alcohol free or to spike it up REAL HARD to the point where certain customers may get drunk. There are also bottled booze that you can serve if you feel like it fits the order of some customers, and even a certain secret drink that could summon secret clients if you serve them to the right people. 

So, this game being a visual novel, where is the "visual novel" part of this? Well, apart from obviously listening to customers tell their stories, serving drinks that either isn't their order or one that fits into someone's "get me a whatever drink" could lead to different conversations happening. And believe me, replaying this game and finding different convos is a treat. Why? Because you LOVE to hear from these characters.

Which brings me to the next part of the review. The characters. The bar may not be a massively popular place for people to be in, but the ones who do come in will be one of the most unique, fun and exciting people to see. People of varying age and personality will come and make sure that you remember them. Hell, some of them will regularly come back to the bar to the point where they'll have their own "the usual" type of drink.

Don't worry; there is an actual story to the game and it's not just a couple hours of serving people drinks and listening to them. While I won't discuss what happens in the story, I'll say one thing for sure: You'll get sad. But in the end, you'll smile.

Another thing to note: the soundtrack is a BANGER. Garoad, the composer of the music made one hell of an OST that WILL stay iconic for decades. Synthwave, City Pop, and house/trap combined into one ass kicking album. Garoad, if you're seeing this - I LOVE YOUR SONGS!!!

The aesthetics are great as well. It feels like you're playing an old 80s/90s PC game, with how sometimes the game goes on slideshow mode and purposefully slows down some animations for a bit of nostalgia feeling. Oh and pixel graphics. I love em as well and it adds to the experience.

The only downsides in the game? Probably only two major things and one minor nitpick; 

[b]Major problems:[/b]

1. In my experience, it took me around 12 hours to finish the game once. Sure, it might seem quite a while for a story, but believe me, once you interacted with the characters, you NEVER want it to end. I'm pretty sure I'm not the only one that wishes we got more time with the patrons in the bar. But then again, there is a story to be told, and in the end, a story's gotta end in the right pace.

2. Model Warrior Julianne. Don't worry; this is not a spoiler by any means, but GÒDDAMN. It's a minigame that Jill can buy for her apartment, it's a bullet hell shoot-em-up with the simple objective of surviving waves of enemies and destroying the final boss, and you have 3 lives. What's the problem?

THE DEVS DEFINITELY DID NOT PLAYTEST THE MINIGAME.

Bullet Hell? MORE LIKE COMPLETIONIST HELL. Anyone who's going for a full 100% run WILL tell you that this minigame is the last achievement anyone goes for and is the hardest. I don't even know how to describe it. It's the Dark Souls of Bullet Hells, there's no I-frames and if you die there's no checkpoint. Goodbye bìtches, go back to the starting point!

Is it impossible? Nope. Is it gonna make you want to blow your brains out? Yep.

[b]Minor nitpicks:[/b]

You can't play this game in full windowed mode. Sure, technically NO ONE does that, but I do it so I can stream the game to my friends with audio, and you could only stream a small window if you wanna do that. Oh well, whatever.

[b]TLDR:[/b]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

- Simple yet fun gameplay
- Great story and characters
- Awesome UI/aesthetic 
- Banger soundtrack
- Best Boss (aka Dana) :D

[h1]Cons: (not including the nitpick):[/h1]

- You'd wish the story is longer
- Model Warrior Julianne could go suck a dìck

What rating do I give this game?

[h1]9/10.[/h1]

As the game itself says in the beginning, get some food or drinks before playing. It's a hella chill experience.

Sukeban Games and Garoad - Love yall, and hope that your future projects goes hella well - including N1RV Ann-A! (I know the development for it is kinda rocky but please - we're still waiting...)

129335593.review:
This game is very very dear to me and it's a real shame I can't express my love for it as eloquently as I want to so I'll try and be as concise as possible. As corny as it may sound, this isn't a game. It's more of an experience. I mean that 200%. Never before have I seen any piece of literature or visual novel depict fictional characters in such a real, and human way and for me to have such an everlasting connection to them. I relate a lot to these characters. I empathise with their struggles. I root for them in their weakest moments. I laugh with them, and that's something I haven't been doing far enough.

[i]" I-... Is this guy really gushing over that dumb ass game with the talking corgi? "[/i]

Shut up it's kino I don't care, even when it's being silly I love it.

This is something special. It's so much more than just a 'Bartending Visual Novel'. It's got so much soul and heart and love put into every letter in the dialogue and every pixel on the screen. To date nothing has ever captured the captivation of life and how people go about their lives in such an honest way. I really don't know how they did it.

Don't even get me started on how life-changing the OST is. I listen to Garoad's tracks almost every day and never get tired of it. And when I do I feel a tinge of melancholy because I know that there will never be anything as special as VA-11 HALL-A in my life ever again. 

I honestly feel sorry for the people incapable of feeling the love I feel for this game. I guess it'll just be my own slice of perfection. I am very excited to see what else Sukeban have in store, I am rooting for them as developers and want them to know they have my support. Thank you for everything.

To everyone that bought this game for windows 11. On W11 the game can have a number of game-breaking bugs such as unable to tab out to other applications else the game will freeze and if you set the game to full-screen it will not work at all. 

To fix this problem you go into the game directory and locate the file named "option.ini" (some people will have config.ini instead, they are the same) and you can either delete it or rename it to something else. The game should be working fine after this. Good luck and have fun everyone.

129283527.review:
I feel like Sseth summarized why I love this game better than I could in his 30 second review in the middle of his 17 minute Shipbreaker review 

"When I play one of these 'work for an exploitative corporation' type games, I don't want to quote unquote 'fight the power.' I want to exist within the system, grasping for any semblance of human connection in a society that dehumanizes us down to mere cells in a spreadsheet."

I think that's why I love this game. You're not the hero, you're just some gay ass bartender serving drinks in a hole in the wall in a gigantic city. It feels realistic in that way. Most of us are unexceptional and all we can do is hold on to those we love as the world goes to shit and try to live lives worth living. 

Crippling existentialism aside: if you vibe with this game, you're going to love it. If you don't, you're not going to have a fun time. Both are valid but I would absolutely recomend trying it for yourself.

128208621.review:
I've played for 3.8 hours, but this is enough time to write a preliminary review the game.

Valhalla is a very simple 'game.' It's a visual novel with a bar-tending backdrop. The bar-tending mechanics are extremely simple. The hardest it will get is when a patron will give you a vague description of what they want, leaving it to the player to interpret what the correct drink is. There's no timer for making the drinks. You can fail as many times as it takes to get the right drink out. There is a money mechanic where Jill has to pay rent along with purchasing items stay happy, but I haven't run into [i]any[/i] issues making money and staying above the poverty line.

The laurels of this game rest [u][b]HEAVILY[/b][/u] on the quality of the writing and characters, which thusfar, have been good. It's of particular note to me that unlike a lot of games where you experience the story first hand, in Valhalla the 'story' happens to other characters, who then bring the world and story to you. Jill (thusfar) doesn't interact with the world where things happen, she interacts with customers who show up to Valhalla and present their stories to her.

I'll update this review as I progress farther into the story, because the quality of this game rides so heavily on the story and characters it presents. All the characters I've met thusfar have been unique and well-written enough that you could show me a picture of them, and I could give you their name and bullet points on who they are and how they behaved.

They music is varied and pretty good as well. It suits the game's atmosphere & aesthetic.
