127749515.review:
Ohohohoho. This game. Mwuah. Chef's kiss. 

It is, in my opinion, one of the best visual novels out there. It's got a nice medium between laid back relaxed story telling and actual game play. Some would argue that the game play isn't engaging but this is REALLY not that sort of game. If you want a game where you smash brains in, shoot 5 year-olds on their Christmas Gift Xbox, and beat the Evil King on Drexia this is NOT your game. 

VA-11 Hall-A is a simple game where you sit back and read and try your best not to screw up a fairly simple puzzle...at it's base. But it's got an incredibly engaging story and at some point you'll have to rely on how much you were invested in it's characters to make the right decisions. The wrong decisions only change your ending and don't lock you out though. 

With a story you can experience over and over, characters that are all incredibly deep with stories you can only fit together from what you hear, and humorous dialogue in a rather dark setting.

TL;DR - Great game, lovely story, and relaxing atmosphere. Not a lot of action (obviously) and best played without distractions.

127709877.review:
First the part that may be helpful for you if you have technical problems: For me, going to full screen caused the game to blackscreen with the shortcut for getting back to windowed also not working. My fix was:
1. Going to "options.ini"
2. Changing "AlternateSyncMethod=1" to "AlternateSyncMethod=2"
It seems that for others it was the other way around. Maybe this helps some people with the same problem which would be great because:

This game is absolutely amazing. I love the writing. I love the look. I love the references. I love the music.
This game is just a perfect example of not needing very complicated mechanics to be fun while also bringing some element of freshness with the drink mixing system. It's so chill, just what I needed to calm down after a day of writing a paper for university.
Except the minigame. FUCK THE MINIGAME (I secretly still liked it tho, if you need guides, there are some on YT and the Steam forums).

My time in Va-11 Hall A felt very natural. Despite having no dialogue options I felt myself going "yeah, I would probably have said something like that" most of the time. The characters make sense. The dogs don't. 

Now go and buy this and have some very fun and chaotic evening in the best bar in Glitch City!

127695833.review:
Great game, I love the sci-fi futuristic themes in general. The music is fantastic too.

The gameplay is relatively simple. Before work you can read stories about the world and the setting you live in. When you go to work, you will do what bartenders do: talk to people and take orders and mix drinks. There is a lot of adult humour and general sarcastic humour. There are a lot of references to old movies and literature.

After reading all the dialogue/monologue of the characters I started to relate to a lot of them and felt touched by their stories.

The topic of sexual relationships and common problems involved in them are discussed a lot. The majority of the characters seem to be either bisexual or homosexual (or simply not mentioned). The problems of these relationships are exclusively portrayed to be arguments and such.
Heterosexual relationships are also explored though much less so, and more often than not the hetero relationships are portrayed in a very negative light, lots of cheating, lying, abuse, and even borderline paedophilia (a bar regular, a sex-worker robot, is apparently designed to appear 10-13 years old) is mentioned.
So this is my warning to anyone reading this: the topics in the game can be quite dark and if that offends you or makes you feel uneasy you might not like it.

Also there's lots of cute dogs.

A genuinely amazing game with fun gameplay and an engaging story with very enjoyable characters that made me laugh out loud many times throughout. The story can get heavy at times, emotionally, however there is some very good life advice that one could actually learn something about regarding many different issues life is bound to throw their way, if they're willing to listen and understand. Even if you're not a fan of the cyberpunk setting I wholeheartedly recommend this game, as the good vibes transcend genre barriers. It was a lot of fun to try to memorize the recipes of cocktails, and it made me feel very good to finally get some down, hahaha. Maybe I should pick up bartending, too? This game is beautiful, fun, and very moving. Please please please show your love for it if you enjoy it, it deserves it wholeheartedly. My only gripe is that there's not more! 127107184.review:
[strike] muscular tomboy boss [/strike]

Wonderful relaxing game, it is half visual novel, half simulator, but do not expect that you will be in the center of some epic plot, influencing powerful people as a bartender. There is something major going on in the background, but your character is just an observer, like many others. It is actually more of just witnessing how different characters, which happen to be your clients, with different backgrounds, interact with each other, and go through their own lives

The gameplay is very simple, there is no time limit or anything, so game is pretty easy and not challenging. You don't get to pick lines for your character, you only influence story through choice of drinks you serve. Not controlling what your character say might seem off-putting, but honestly it is not bad thing in this case, dialogues for main character are as much written as any other character, so it's more watching multiple stories from perspective of one character, which has their own issues too.

Artstyle, atmosphere, setting, music, gameplay, whatever you find in this game attractive, is just a nice bonus, a pretty wrapping. What actually makes this game unique and stand out from others and worth appreciating it for is well written dialogues. You will get to see characters talk about their personal issues, going through different problems, and some advices they say, or words of comfort, are genuinely decent things, or good thoughts worth thinking about. It is not something very deep, but perhaps there is something you will find yourself relate to, maybe some of those words is what you need to hear

If that sounds appealing to you, then it's time to mix drinks and change lives.

[h1][i] Time to mix drinks and change lives [/i][/h1]
─────────────────────────────────────
[i]VA-11 HALL-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action is a booze em' up about waifus, technology, and post-dystopia life. I found it to have a very deep and entertaining story that I could not take my eyes of the screen. It also features an awesome soundtrack that fits well with enviroment. [/i]

[h1][i] Characters [/i][/h1]
────────────
[i]   Let's talk about our lovely goth gf main character first. Jill Stingray is simply the best bartender you could ask for, she's charismatic, beautiful, skinny and gothic and knows how to deal with any kind of people who enters through VA-11 Hall-A doors. Then there's the badass, white-haired, wrestling champion, owner of VA-11 Hall-A, Dana Zane. I could tell from the begining that she was going to be my comfy character. Next is the cat boomer, best girl and owner of my heart Stella Hoshi. When Stella first came into picture I was like "yeah, that's her, she's definitely my waifu and no one will take her place", she's kind, cute, stunning  and care a lot about the people in her life. I also need to mention our big tits blonde hacker Alma Armas, which I fell in love since she appeared on the screen, she may be the best friend one can ask for. 
   There are a lot of other awesome characters in the game but this ones are special to me. Oh and I was almost forgetting about Gil, well what can I tell you guys about him? He's a....hmm...well he's.... I guess no one knows who he is, but one thing I can say for sure, he's definitely a bartender in VA-11 Hall-A.[/i]

[h1][i] Conclusion [/i][/h1]
────────────
[i]    From now on this is going to be my comfy game. Everything is perfect, the gameplay is simple and fun, the soundtrack is simply fantastic, the characters amazing  and the story is so good that makes me want to play it again and again. It took me about 16 hours to beat the game which I found it to be a nice amount of time for a VN. I really don't have anything bad to say about it and I strongly recommend you play it!
Congrats to all the devs and artists that made the game a reality! [/i]

(10/10)

125732142.review:
This game was beyond excellent! 
It has a very in-depth story and every single character is fleshed out and given a personality and subject matter to discuss that's unique to them. 
It's a very simple game, though.
The only "input" you provide, besides clicking through dialogue, is serving drinks using a simple interface. However, the story is so intricately woven that you end up getting absorbed into it and don't mind the simplicity of the game's functions. In fact, you'll find that the gameplay becomes secondary to the story. I found myself fully enthralled and engaged by the storyline and kept wanting to learn more about every character that decided to stop by. 
This was a wonderful game worth playing and I'm glad I got the opportunity to play it.

125550034.review: I adore this game. Va-11 Hall-A is so unbelievably enjoyable to me. I'm not the type to usually enjoy visual novels but the unique writing, style, and humor just struck a chord with me; I'm a real sucker for cyberpunk dystopian future storytelling and the writing adds many subtler, plot points as well. This game doesn't treat you like a child, it doesn't stray away from touching on a few darker themes and it also rewards you for your thoroughness; unlocking extra dialogue and getting a few extra lines by making certain choices throughout the game, It presents these themes in an organic, thoughtful way, giving you a few puzzle pieces, and trusting you to put them together to gain the bigger picture. Garoad's soundtrack is also one of my favorite in gaming, with a lot of future synth (?) to really immerse you in the world that this game has built for you. I highly recommend just getting this game to relax, enjoy the story, and indulge in some cyberpunk bartender action!!

125345690.review:
really phenomenal game. i'm not usually one for visual novels but this one just hooked me immediately. there is something incredibly inviting and endearing about the universe created in VA-11 Hall-A - the cyberpunk world that's built solely through conversations and various news articles/other social medias is so fascinating and interesting to learn more about. 

it's astonishing how rich and deeply developed the lives of these characters become simply from brief chats held with them every day or so. i've seen another review claim the dialogue is awkward and cringe-y, yet nothing could be farther from my own opinion. i really enjoyed the dialogue and found it very refreshing; maybe it's just because i don't play many visual novels, but the conversations always felt very real (or at least as real as a cyberpunk game can get). i also really adore the mini social media experience we get in between shifts; reading the articles and especially the forum posts is so entertaining and helps establish the world even more. 

there is also the drink making aspect, but it feels like such a small part of Va-11 Hall-A as a whole that it's barely even worth mentioning. there's nothing really astounding or unique about it, though it does help break up any monotony the player might be feeling from reading so much text. it can get a bit tiresome at some points to go through the motions, but it never gets annoying by any means. there's also a few general "choices" you can make based on the drinks you serve, which can unlock certain endings with characters.

couple of little shout outs: the music is SO awesome. garoad is a mf genius. every track is a banger and fits the atmosphere so well. genuinely one of the best game osts i've ever heard. 

the main character, Jill, is a fuckin' legend and i adore her. she's super grounded, almost to the point of being a sort of "straight man" to the other character's eccentricities, but it works really great and makes her super relatable to see through the eyes of. they've written her so well; there's never a reaction or dialogue she has that feels weird or nonsensical. she's funny and charming and goes through some really wonderful character growth. 

actually, for that matter, all the characters are written really great, especially the women. there are some less-likable folk that populate the bar from time to time, but there's never really any character that i hate seeing. each of their unique experiences come together to create a wonderfully cohesive view of a futuristic city rife with corruption and an odd charm. 



ok, end of review: i really can't recommend this game enough. it has this certain vibe that is totally unmatched and unique to anything else i've played. there are moments in this game that have genuinely moved me, and i am completely fascinated by the universe that has been so lovingly created. i'm so excited for the sequel. please get this game!!!

Stilted and awkward dialog asks for too much reading between the lines considering what is presented upfront is quite shallow. Like reading my own cringey IM conversations or an AI talking to an AI.  Is Jill Stingray, who experiences the future through the grapevine while seeing and experiencing almost nothing beyond the drudgery of her day job and who is behind the curtains given a voice by a man with a chiseled jawline, evidence of the moral imperative to hire 15 writers and 10 consultants on all creative projects and price indies out of the market by badgering them to do the same? Perhaps I need to play PC-98 soft porn to fully understand. I often felt as if my game had been hacked to include modded content (hacked by Alice Rabbit?). When a new character would pop up I was left wondering if this could really be in the official game due to the slapdash nature of every encounter. Listen to the soundtrack, skip the game.

124328760.review:
VA-11 Hall-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action is a boozing VN in a post-dystopia cyberpunk future reminiscent of 80s and 90s scifi anime.  Beat it first time around in somewhere between 13-14 hours using a mouse and keyboard for shortcuts.  Difficulty is easy.  Not for kids cause of the booze and half the stuff they talk about.

This game is awesome and a masterpiece.  If the next one comes out, I will be snatching it up instantly.  I have only good things to say about this game.  

Graphics - Reminiscent of the PC-98.  If that doesn't tell you anything, then look at the screenshots in the store.  That's what you're getting.  While everything is smooth and spiffy for current day computer enjoyment, you can still apply oldschool scanlines in the settings if you want.  

Story - For 18ish in-game days, a bunch of robots, lgbtq+ people, and talking corgis hang out at a back-alley bar and talk about life in the equivalence of Neo Detroit.  Jumbled together in pieces over the game are a few different character stories, main character story, and through it all you need to raise enough cash to pay rent.  

Endings - There's more than one ending.  I originally got the bad ending and I was not disappointed.

Achievements - There are a bunch of achievements.  You get an achievement for starting up the game a second time.  Do Eet.  

Hidden Stuff and Keyboard shortcuts - VA-11 Hall-A goes the extra oldschool mile by having a few hidden things.  Hidden drinks, hidden characters, and stuff you just want to find to round out the experience with extraness.  There are also keyboard shortcuts that aren't explained out in game (as far as I know).  I found them when I went to the guides.  The most important one is qwerty +/- shift can manually add or remove ingredients from a drink for when you mess up and don't want to waste.  Now you know.

Optional Bonus Stuff - The game has an optional prequel of what happened for three days before the game, as well as an optional prequel for one of Jill's weirder customers.  

Music - Best music.  Ever.   They aren't selling it on steam so I went to the developer's store and ordered it on CD.  This happened sometime in the first 4 hours of playing.  Was unprepared for how much I love the soundtrack.  I listen to it while I drive, work, and chill out.  

Booze - The atmosphere in the game reminds me of bars I've gone to, but with extra future bits.  It made me want to drink.  This could be good or bad depending on how you interpret.  Being the bartender, I got characters drunk instead.  



Va-11 Hall-A is worth it.  If you like VNs, bars, corgis, androids, cyborgs, cat people, booze, good music, and 90's scifi anime, you have no reason not to buy this game.

124324349.review:
It's a bar in a dystopian cyberpunk universe. Wait, don't go! This is a bar you'll actually want to spend time in. Even if the dogs mess it up from time to time (bad dogs!). It's a visual novel and skill game all in one. You're a bartender, mixing drinks from compounds for your customers. Who are about as varied as you can imagine. And, actually interesting. Really, the entire story has been interesting so far, and I can't recommend this highly enough.

A few minutes later . . . 

Okay, I thought of more stuff. The dialog between Jill and her cat is priceless. Yes, the cat talks, did I stutter? If there are talking dogs, talking cats would be obvious because cats rule, dogs drool. My cat made me say that.

It's the unexpected directions the game goes in, the dialog which sometimes is far more insightful than it should be. I played it once before, and am coming back to it again fresh and rediscovering the little things in it that you go "Oh, that's different." 

Okay, buy this now.

124009373.review:
AITA for not letting my daughter buy clothes?
My wife (37f) and I (37m) have 4 kids (14f and 14m, 12m, and 11f), we generally agree on parenting them, but a recent incident had me and my wife disagreeing and I want to see if I was in the wrong.

A few weeks ago, I was at home with our 12 y/o because he was sick with a stomach bug. While I was making him soup, I got a call from my twin’s high school, telling me that they wanted to speak with me, and that my daughter had received 3 days of ISS for a bullying incident. Because of my son’s sickness, I spoke through them via phone and they told me everything that had happened, my daughter and a group of her friends was picking on a boy for wearing a crop top, the boy told the teacher, she asked them to stop, when they didn’t stop, she sent them to the office. After talking to the boy, he admitted the bullying was going on for a few days, and that they kept bothering him when he asked them to stop.

My daughter and son came home and my son’s face was bright red. I told my daughter to go to her room and then sat down with my son to see if he was okay. Apparently the boy she bullied was a close friend of his, one of his football teammates. The boy was talking to my son and their other friends and said something about how he thought it was cool that some men used to wear sports crop tops. The boys told him if he thought it was cool, he should try it. The boys went out and bought some jerseys from the thrift store and made them into crop tops.

I then spoke to my daughter, she didn’t show much remorse and was dismissive of me, last year she also got in trouble for bullying someone bc of clothing, she’s also gotten in trouble for racism at school (very white area, we are white, her and her friends were saying racist stuff in class). When my wife got home, we discussed a punishment and agreed on not buying her new clothes for a while, she has plenty of good clothes already.

This weekend, we went to visit my brother. My brother lives around 3 hours away in a small town and we don’t see him often. This week was the town’s annual fair. At the fair, they had booths from local businesses.

Our oldest son went to the booth with antique sports stuff and then the book booth to get books on sports history (son loves reading those), our 12 y/o got some plushies and toys and our youngest was looking at video games.

Our oldest daughter went to the clothes, I stopped her and told her the rule was still in place. I said she could buy books, a video game, candy, ect, but clothes were the one thing she could not get. She was bugging my wife and my wife eventually told her she would reconsider it, she then talked to me and I told her that I wasn’t changing my stance because I am letting her buy other stuff and I thought she was being entitled, my daughter didn’t buy anything and my wife thinks I was too tough on her. When I called my mom for advice, she also agreed with my wife, AITA?

123008074.review: Good but not great. I love the vibe of this game, but I'm kinda so-so on the execution. The music is fantastic, absolutely stunningly superb for an indie game. The character design is good and I love the pixel art style and environment design, but I'm not a fan of the particular anime style the character portraits use—it feels kind of rough and inconsistent. The bartending mechanics are maybe a bit too simplistic, though having to remember or guess at what some characters want adds just enough challenge. The story and world-building are fun and inspirational. I'll chime in with some other reviewers who also think that the sexual content in many of the characters' conversations gets a bit tedious. (Also, Dorothy is gross and, like, transparently a pedophile's fantasy; her inclusion actively makes the game worse.) Overall, worth checking out.

122936148.review:
I remember hearing the buzz about this game when it first came out. I ignored it. I don't know why really as someone who is pretty much a lifelong fan of all things Japan. I guess it was the visual novel tag ? Not sure. I mean I enjoy anime and manga but never started walking the path of VNs. 

Anyway ! I'm enjoying this game. Very casual, very light and easy to follow. You will encounter customers from all walks of cyberpunk life, along with topics that cover a broad spectrum of things - and there is a lot covered ! The drinks making element is super simple. I think this game is all about the world building and painting that grim (or not) vision of the future which is largely contributed by a sprinkling of varied and interesting characters that all have something to offer the story.

Graphics are right up my street as I love the nostalgia of pixel art and scanlines. Music is above average and also quite nostalgic of 90's anime tv series imo.  Speaking of which I did spot the Bubblegum Crisis reference via a character name - this really made me smile as I adored that series. To summarise, I would say if you enjoy anime or manga or Japanese pop culture this is a must buy. Can't compare it to other Visual Novels as this is my first one. I recommend !

121753105.review:
VA-11 Hall-A: Cyberpunk Bartender Action itself is a lot like the titular bar the game takes place in 

In the sea of a consistently unpleasant world and all of those other games on your desktop you usually end up playing instead, VA-11 Hall-A is sitting there, often overlooked or set aside in favor of something more kinetic and directly engaging. 

But for those nights when everything else is frustrating you, none of your friends are on, and you'd just like to play something nice to unwind before bed, VA-11 Hall-A is a warm, inviting beacon. A nice little venue for you to relax in as you allow yourself to be immersed in the charming and frequently hilarious dialogue, endearing characters, gentle gameplay loop, delightful synth soundtrack, and frankly drop-dead gorgeous pixel art. Before long, you'll be on another playthrough, working towards getting a different ending out of the six possible. 

So go on, bartender. Mix some drinks and change some lives.

121751955.review: Vee ei eleven hall ei. The synthetic bartending visual novel filled to the brim with drinks, girls, heartrending sorrow, overcoming said sorrow, dogs, innuendos, and relatable life advice. An absolute joy to play through if you're a fan of visual novels, anime, or if you're alone on a Saturday night. The dialog's amazing, the soundtrack's a "banger," I believe is what the kids call it, the gameplay's pretty simple, but it does make grinding for unique dialogue the old-fashioned way a bit of a nightmare, but there are guides for that. Definitely one of my favorite games of all time. Try it out if you haven't! You, too, can mix drinks and change lives.

121715931.review:
good music that sets the mood, gameplay that is simple but offers its own challenges and cryptic order, it is fun getting familiar with the drinks and the customers to get the order right to discover certain responses. Even the act of balancing money to fulfill rent in the end of the month got me nervously try serve more expensive drinks at the last few days and hope they don't notice.

but really, having people just sit there, talking about struggles of relationship, career choices, and how they cope.. and those lonely moments in the apartment scrolling the news where big things happen but can't do anything about it... and those personal moment taking a break and having a heart to heart with someone is just.. what I needed.

VA-11 Hall-A is a pleasant game all around. I absolutely adore the sprite-work in this game, and the music is one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard. The story and universe is nothing to scoff at, there's a lot of substance to immerse yourself in. I don't particularly enjoy talking about immersion, since I personally have troubles entering a world created by someone else - this game is a beautiful exclusion from that role.

I really only have one negative thing to say about this game, and that's the gameplay is very minimal. When you first buy this game, have in mind that you're looking for a visual novel with bartender elements, not a bartender simulator that's also a visual novel. Obviously it's difficult to expect this game being a high octane drink mixing game, so this isn't anything to really knock the game for, as the simple nature and lack of challenge was the intention behind its development. Despite that comment, I honestly recommend this game to anyone who wants to play a game that is both immersive and calm.

121586856.review:
I've seen this game described as "a cyberpunk story like Blade Runner or 2077 except the POV character has no relevance to that plot at all" and I'd say that's 100% accurate.

A visual novel that perfectly achieves its goal of being a cozy, low-stakes way to unwind. Every character is well-rounded and fun to interact with - even the player character, who is a main player in the story in her own right rather than an avatar of you.

The couple of downsides I can list are maybe a bit too much ambition with the [i]number[/i] of characters - several are set up and have the game end before their arcs can really feel "concluded" or "paid off" - and some important story beats are hidden behind a tiny button on the main menu without it being explained when you should play them.

That said, I finished the main story and desperately wanted more - so clearly this slice of life is doing something right!

SKŁADNIKI:
500 g mięsa wieprzowego (np. karkówki)
200 g kiełbasy
1 cebula
2 łyżki oleju roślinnego
3 szklanki bulionu lub wody
30 g suszonych borowików
2 łyżki powideł śliwkowych lub kilka suszonych śliwek
1 jabłko (np. reneta lub antonówka) - opcjonalnie
1 kg kiszonej kapusty
1 łyżka koncentratu pomidorowego
1 łyżka mąki
1 łyżka masła

Mięso pokroić w kostkę. Cebulę pokroić w kosteczkę i zeszklić na oleju w dużym garnku. Dodać mięso i dokładnie je obsmażyć.
Wlać 2 szklanki gorącego bulionu lub wody z solą i pieprzem, zagotować. Następnie dodać połamane suszone grzyby, przykryć, zmniejszyć ogień i gotować przez ok. 45 minut.
Dodać listek laurowy, ziela angielskie, kminek, majeranek, powidła śliwkowe lub posiekane śliwki, obrane i pokrojone w kosteczkę obrane jabłko i wymieszać.
Dodać odciśniętą kiszoną kapustę oraz wlać szklankę wody, wymieszać. Przykryć i gotować przez ok. 15 minut.
Kiełbasę obrać ze skóry, pokroić w kostkę i podsmażyć na patelni. Dodać do kapusty i gotować przez ok. 30 minut. Pod koniec dodać koncentrat pomidorowy.
Mąkę podsmażyć na suchej patelni, gdy zacznie brązowieć dodać łyżkę masła i mieszać aż masło się rozpuści.
Trzymając patelnię na ogniu dodać stopniowo kilka łyżek kapusty cały czas mieszając. Przełożyć zawartość patelni z powrotem do garnka, wymieszać i zagotować.

120817551.review:
Just as fun as I remembered it, played this game back on the Vita and it was just amazing.

[h2]Gameplay:[/h2]
Bartending. It's in the title! Jokes aside, the bartending is basically just following a recipe and doing specific things to make drinks. It's not in depth or anything but a nice thing to break up the reading since this game is entirely a VN. 

[h2]Story:[/h2]
Characters are great, setting is interesting, lots of extra stuff to read in the section before the day starts as well as tons of dialogue variations that make each playthrough slightly more unique than the last since there are some orders that you have to interpret yourself that changes dialogue. There's also multiple endings. [b]Do keep in mind that this is NOT a game where your choices matter.[/b] What you do does affect what dialogue you get but it has no real consequences aside from not seeing extra character scenes or losing money.

[h2]Presentation:[/h2]
Good art style, good music (you can set up your favorites at the start of the day, skip forward etc thanks to the jukebox). Overall very good presentation. 

[h2]Playtime:[/h2] 
Not very long depending on how fast you read. Looking for round 10 hours for a casual playthrough trying to finish the game and see every ending, longer if you want to see every single dialogue variation (there's a ton)

[h2]Postgame/Extras:[/h2]
Aside from getting the extra endings and achievements, there's a 3 day? prequel alongside a slight prologue after you finish the main story that are basically extra content to read and explore. Not much else though.

[h2]Verdict:[/h2]
Buy it, its only $15 and it's worth your time. If you're tight on cash wait for a sale. Game makes up for the short playtime with lots of charm and personality

120694642.review:
pros:
- gorgeous pixel artwork
- likeable and dislikable characters a plenty
- consistently good and funny writing
- fantastic music
- a cyberpunk game that actually understands what the setting is meant to be
- also a cyberpunk game where you only *hear* about various events going on but never see them first hand
- really unique and fun little bartending minigame

cons:
- some plotlines and details are left unresolved
- bizarre nonsensical references to real world things (ooh boy that yiik reference though...)
- falls to cyberpunk cliches of neon and orientalism despite not being set in japan
- theres a godawful shmup minigame which you need to beat for an achievement and it manages to successfully ignore any detail that makes that genre good or enjoyable

overall, its 100% worth picking up imho because whilst some bits are left unresolved, its ultimately great fun from start to finish. i adored my time with this game, barring when i was playing the shmup minigame. definitely grab this if you havent already.

120690820.review:
I had this game in my library for a while. My best friend and I have played games together in the past. One day I just booted this up and began playing. It was common for us to voice different characters. It wasn't long until our other friends joined in via Discord. Over the next couple weeks we played this game and enjoyed it a ton. The characters, the setting, the story. It was a wonderful and very memorable time.

This is NOT your average visual novel type game. I'm not usually into the genre, but something about the aesthetics and the unique drink mixing mechanic really make this game special. There is even a fair amount of replay value due to the different possible interactions and endings. Currently I am working on finding all the secrets (alone) but I'm still enjoying my time.

Needless to say, I am very excited for the sequel. Whenever it does come out. I'm watching the dev's website carefully. I know about the issues with development, and I understand making games takes a long time. I say take all the time you need. I want the game to turn out great. My friends and I will be here when its ready :)

120474235.review:
I swore I would never make one of these again, but it appears the cards were stacked against me from the very beginning. I have pursued a life of sin, hoping to find meaning in the nothingness of the world. I was on a journey to capitalize on the vices of this world, or in other words I was on a con quest (conquest) of the varied tea (verity). But I should've known: the house always wins. You see, on my journey to the center of the earth [located 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea (undressing)] I came across a man with a scraggly beard and a penchant for the wicked. He reached into his loins and handed me a dirty 10 quid, which I begrudgingly accepted. Now just between you and me, 10 quid is a lot of moolah. So much moolah that all the cows went "moo lah lah" in unison like a choir of twinks. The winning lottery numbers are 24, 14, 58, 2, 38, and 5. I spent the 10 quid on a fresh ride. I'm talking 5gum levels of fresh. Even the people from Pimp my Ride were baffled at how dripped out my whip was. It was so dripped out that they couldn't even pimp it. Anyways back to what I was originally talking about, do Rice Krispies Treats even have a slogan? They definitely don't, right? Which is weird considering they're so popular. And the 3 twinks that are always on the boxes? Don't even get me started on them. If I have 10 cans of Axe body spray and I give 4 of them to my friend Bartholomew, what do I now have? That's right, bad taste. Or is it bad smell? These are the kinds of questions that philosophers such as Aristotle, Plato, Socrates, and Eric Carle have been thinking about for centuries, because they have all lived that long. That begs the question, is Eric Carle still alive? It feels like he published one book and then disappeared off to Narnia, no doubt to find the answer to the moral quandary. Long story short, I was able to bypass the first layer of the quadlock, but I was stumped at the second and the third. The fourth was slight work, since I had acquired the peanut of truth and prosperity. In the middle of the pocket laid a hand made of flesh and bone, but it was not human. No, it was the flesh and bone of an animal. How could it have a hand in this?

Sometimes when I look into the mirror I see myself, but sometimes when I look into the mirror I see myself.

120003904.review:
(minor spoilers, nothing big)

First off, let's start with the tags. This game is defenitely cyberpunk, but I am not really sure about the visual novel thing. It is not a regular VN. From what I know, you cannot do anything else than serve drinks. That's how the game decides what ending you get and what conversations you take part in. You don't get to choose the things your character says. All the characters you encounter are pretty interesting and the story is quite deep once you know the context. It's a pity that reading the news does practically nothing. It would be great if it could unlock a new customer or something like that. The act of serving drinks is fun and I like that you sometimes may choose the drink you serve on your own or decide whether you want to get your customer drunk. The plot is amazing overall and the graphics are beautiful (it's pixels, duh..). And the music! Every time you get to work, you choose some songs in the jukebox that play throughout the conversations. There are many achievements you can try to get. There are also multiple endings, and so there's some replay value too! That's it. If you won't regret spending about 10 Euros on a singleplayer and a rather short game, you should definitely buy VA-11 Hall-A!

119635912.review:
La verdad es que es una pena darle una puntuación negativa al juego pero es que este falla en lo mas importante en este tipo de juegos: [b] La Trama [/b].

Realmente solo hay 3 personajes interesantes cuando resulta que hay unos 30 en total.
Si terminé el juego fue por ver el final de los personajes ya que estuve a punto de abandonarlo. Tras ver el final (y finales alternativos en youtube) reconozco que no merecía la pena terminarlo. 

- El diseño esta bien aunque un par de personajes tienen un diseño que parece fuera un estilo artístico diferente al resto y rompen la sintonia.

- La música si bien es variada y no está mal, es elegida a gusto del jugador como si fuera un tocadisco de modo que es "al azar" en el sentido de que no encaja con las situaciones o personajes (excepto en muy contadas ocasiones que el juego fuerza una concreta).

- La jugabilidad es la típica de una novela visual y la parte de hacer bebidas pierde la novedad rápidamente y se vuelve mas algo tedioso que interesante. Incluso piden recordar bebidas de clientes habituales de modo que penaliza al jugador por jugar esporádicamente y no de seguido por olvidarse.

- La trama como decía es lo que peor lleva el juego. Hay conversaciones muy largas que no llevan a nada y que apenas si son relevantes. Las tramas de algunos personajes son literalmente la gracia de parezco X pero soy Y sin llegar a ser algo mas por si mismos. Hay personajes insoportables y otros que son demasiado normales como para generar interés alguno.

En resumidas cuentas, el juego prometía pero se queda en algo un tanto mediocre.  [b] No es que sea malo [/b] pero no merece la pena las horas de juego que se invierten. 
Curiosamente lo han relacionado internamente con otro juego llamado 2064: Read Only Memories el cual, si bien tiene algún cliché descarado que otro en su trama, es en general bastante mejor juego y lo recomiendo antes que VA-11 HALL-A

119552646.review:
I never sniffed a drug as hard as this one. 

The dialogue has so much humor, while at the same time, being so mature. 
It's incredible how a VN about serving drinks can be so fun and [strike]addicting[/strike]. 
The characters can be cheesy sometimes, but they feel really unique and contribute to the atmosphere of a cyberpunk dystopia; I loved every single one of them, and that doesn't happen to me all that much; I use to not like some characters in vidya who might feel pretentious, but this game doesn't have a single one that I'd punch in the face.
Hell, I don't even make reviews anymore, and here I am, writing after a 100% completion with 558 minutes in session, with the intro scene looping.
Seriously tho, the only thing I have to hate about this game, is that it makes you go through it again if you didn't make the right decisions 'till the end (which is not that bad, to be honest, considering there is a lot of hidden dialogue and endings behind actions and such), and the other one is just for 100% completion, which is the stupid shoot 'em up mini-game, being this mediocre, frustrating 5 minute level about the same enemy, which is super spammy while you don't have i-frames or anything after you die. Pure pain, even when you cheese it like I did; it's just that bad. 
Aside from that, this is a must-buy IMO, even if you don't EVEN care about this types of games, the experience here is rather unique. 
Music is top notch too, it has a lot of effort put into it. 
I don't really like VNs in general, not even eroges; but this game man, this game just has it all. 
The story is a really compelling one, you really feel for the characters, even the smuggest villain-looking ones have a hardship, a regret, or something they miss; they're just well written in general. Some, I like more than others, but that's more for you to judge, I personally didn't like Donovan that much, tho it's just made for that regard, I guess.  

Bottom line is: Buy it, it won't ever go on sale, I'm afraid, so don't wait for a red moon.

119100681.review:
I have a lot of mixed feelings about this game.

On the one hand, I thought a lot of the characters were very loveable. On the other, I feel as though the guy who wrote this projected his feelings toward women and how he clearly thinks they are/should be into the game A LOT. I got a lot of internalized misogyny from Alma's plot arc, and the existence of Dorothy as a character herself was very strange and uncomfortable for me. That may have been the point of that, though. 

Those things aside, a lot of the characters were very interesting and had a lot of dimension to them, so much so that I played the game fully and am considering an NG+ run to get the full picture of things and try to get all of the achievements. After my first play-through and as of writing this review, there are some things I'm curious about that I would like to know more about that weren't fully revealed to me by the end of it. Hopefully that's a thing that I can do.

The soundtrack to this game is incredible, and I love the art, although, as an artist myself, I felt some designs for specific characters could have been better.

All-in-all, I appreciate the game for what it is. I wouldn't say it's a perfect game, but I do still hold a good amount of regard for it. So yeah, I'd recommend it, so long as you take it with a grain of salt. Buy it when it's on sale.

When you play it for the first time, don't look at any guides, or any external content about the game.  It dulls the experience if you do.

Once you've complete the game, make sure to [spoiler]click the blue plus at the top left of the title screen and play all three prologue days, and the two Anna days that unlock immediately below.  After playing through the two "Anna" parts, replay "Anna Start" trying every dialogue option.[/spoiler]  That'll get you the last bit of content; a strange narrative break from the rest of the visual novel.

The extra pieces of post-main story content, plus having time and space to process the game and it's plot has propelled it from good to amazing.

One of the most immersive games I have ever played.
VA-11 Hall-A sells its world like few other stories manage. It convinced me that - just for the duration of the game - I really lived in a tiny apartment in a futuristic dystopian metropolis and went to work at a shabby bar every night to earn my rent.

A cozy and heartwarming story that will sting at times - but is definitely worth it.

118472934.review:
I can say, the actual bar-tending mixing mechanic did take a little bit of getting used to. It took me a while to figure out how to mix drinks properly and how drinks become completely mixed, though after that the game was really interesting and a smooth ride with the drink making mechanic.

I had fun figuring out the stories of the different people that entered the bar and growing attachment to some, as well as attachment to my fellow co-workers. This game is a very chill game for if you want hands on activity, plot, and just plain entertainment throughout. Some customers can get annoying, though they were definitely created with that in mind. I

I enjoy the music as well, having a fun time setting up the jukebox with different music throughout the day and finding new music that I really enjoy listening to while "working"! The art style is unique and a lot of fun, as well as the idea of having to worry about how much money you are making, what things you can buy to boost your mood, and what decorations you might want.

I enjoy playing as an actual character and not myself, as it helps immerse me into the game play and plot-line, having a character who I am that  I also have to learn more about throughout the gaming process.

Overall, this game is perfect for someone like me, who enjoys laid back game play, plot-line, music, and art. 10/10 in my book.

I played this game for a couple hours after seeing some people play it on Youtube. I did not like this game whatsoever. It has almost no game-play, as expected of a visual novel. But it has this annoying bar mini-game where you make drinks for the patrons by mixing different ingredients together in set recipes. It did not work for me, and mostly just took me out of the dialogue that the characters were having.

Speaking of characters, this game has quite a few. Most of them were at least somewhat interesting and fun, but none of them really made me care for anything that was happening. Dorothy was kind of interesting I guess, Dana was there. The guy that kept ordering large beers was pretty boring. I'm not sure if they got more interesting later in the game. But if it didn't catch my attention in 2 hours worth of game-play then I am not interested.

The game is competently made and has nice character sprites. No bugs or technical issues whatsoever and the UI is fine. No complaints here.

Overall, I dislike this game as I find it boring. However, I do think that a lot of people might like it so I can recommend it as it is competently made and has interesting ideas. I think I am in the minority. Try the game out if you are interested.

118184165.review:
The first review I have ever written, and am I glad it is on this masterpiece.

[h1]VA-11 HALL-A: Humanity in a Cocktail[/h1][hr][/hr]
Emotion and discussions of humanity has been steadily solidifying its place as a zeitgeist in the medium of games, early examples being heartstring tuggers like To the Moon, and prime examples being more recent, refined titles such as Undertale and Papers, Please.

It's no secret that games with heart such as these have their fair share of mimics, and other titles trying to capitalize on the boom, only to leave behind shallow messages that fall flat, or end up tokenizing everything to a point of superficiality and irritation on the part of the player.

VA-11 HALL-A does not fall into that category.

VA-11 HALL-A has a simple premise. Follow instructions, make cocktails, and listen as patrons line up text on the bottom of the screen. You're going to get little more than that. Only a little. And did the writers make full use of that routine.

Behind the counter, or screen, in your case, the player is treated to a narrative that discusses much and more about the little dilemmas, joys and sorrows of the human experience, and all that comes from a catgirl. In this genre, it is all too common to have a silent protagonist. The 'You, Player, are the Protagonist' approach that either can lend so much more to the experience, or - in far too many cases - lead to the protagonist ending up as a wet soggy cut-out with the smudged scrawl of 'Self-Insert LOL' written on their forehead. Not here.

Every single character is well defined, and part of the story. There is no character reduced to being a vehicle for a narrative, presented 'dialogue options' for the sole purpose of eliciting a canned reaction from another.

That's the beauty of this game, really. With such established characters, and strong personalities even on the protagonist's part, you, the player, also has a say in this story. Your decisions matter. Not in the sense that it will irreparably alter the course of the gameplay, but it's the little things.

Will you take the extra few seconds out of your time to make a drink bigger for a patron who's celebrating Friday? You don't have to do it, but will you? Will you willingly get an order wrong for a patron, simply because you know that they like sweeter things than sour things? It will mess up your perfect bonus.

Will you be kind in the little things, for the sake of being kind?

So there's all that, and there's also the larger picture. The world building is subtle and polished. The humor is on point with its simplicity. Though, really, children shouldn't be playing this. The soundtrack is crafted immaculately to the setting. The art is what you'd expect - good pixel art, but the character designs are memorable without being gaudy.

Best birthday present I ever received, but it is worth the full price, or at the very least, a top pick for a sale impulse buy.

I'll replay this just to feel like I'm catching up with old friends again. 

Time to mix drinks, and change lives. Who knew the recipe for empathy is that simple.

118110151.review:
Oh man! I've got a lot to say! This'll be long, so review summary up front. I waited to 100% this game for a review, so I've played it thoroughly!

This is an insta-buy at full price if you like: visual novels, cyberpunk, anime aesthetic, waifu memery, or any game with really good atmosphere. If you don't fall into those categories, I still recommend you give this a try. I'm not a visual novel person, but I the writing and atmosphere really won me over, not to mention it has an incredible soundtrack. But if you're hesitant, wait for a sale and pick it up anyway. This game has a lot of heart and surprising depth.

On to the full review! 

For starters, I'm a bartender, hence part of my interest in this game. I love what I do so I'm drawn to seeing the subject portrayed, particularly in video games. The integration of bartending mechanics into the game itself is brilliant. I will say the sound effects are very very realistic, and the fictional portrayal of mixology in a cyberpunk dystopia is intriguing and surprisingly plausible. 

With that out of the way, let me start with the positives and I'll conclude with the negatives. 

This game hooked me out of the gate with the gorgeous visuals. The art is obviously very lovingly done, and it really helps carry the game. All the characters are colorful and interesting. The bar itself is lovely. They absolutely nailed the neon soaked cyberpunk dystopia. It's not the most original world they've created, but it's one of my favorite depictions of it. With that said, what really pulled me in was the music. I have to give it a 9/10. It's such a perfect fit for the setting and it's utterly entrancing. Seriously, load your juke box up every shift with a variety, you'll fall in love with at least a couple.

Well, this is a visual novel, so the really important question is, how's the writing? 

It's incredibly solid. Especially since this isn't a romantic VN, the conversations are so much more organic, love isn't getting shoe horned into every topic. People just- talk like people. As a bartender myself, it's all very familiar. I'd bet money some of the writers have done their time behind the stick, it shows. The characters are all very distinct, and the ones who feel trite at first reveal some depth by the end. The game has a perfect length to allow everyone to get a chance in the spot light and come through. The writing is also fairly self aware, for example the character who is a sex worker who looks like a stereotypical anime girl actually talks about that in length over the course of the story, going through her thoughts, experiences and showing it's not just an excuse for the writers to have a hot anime school girl involved. The characters around her simultaneously take her seriously and act appropriately to her behavior, as well. It's a breath of fresh air.

This actually brings me to something I wanted to say, it's not exactly a critique but the up-front marketing of this game is not particular accurate or helpful? When I purchased the game on a whim I expected a game about hitting on anime girls from behind the bar, but that is absolutely not what you get. One ending involves romance. The rest of the game involves making drinks and getting to know people and hearing about their lives, finding out what makes them who they are. Almost none of the characters show a romantic or sexual interest in the protagonist. This is, again, quite refreshing. This game is surprisingly grounded and subtle.

Well... Mostly. Let's say a solid 3/4 or 7/8 of it is amazing and it really pulls you in. You start to care about the characters and their endings are very satisfying if you put in the work. However...

There is some sloppy writing in the mix, and a strange obsession with /b/ is obviously on the peripherals of the game. It's strange seeing 4chan references- even if this game did come out in 2016- but it's there, and it doesn't do much to add to this game. In fact, it cheapens it. There's a character who's built to spam the screen with /b/ like dialogue and it's honestly obnoxious and does little to help the story. I'm not a fan of references that are used like bludgeons. 

This isn't the only example, too. Despite being well written and enjoyable characters in their own right, there's almost always one conversation per female character about their chest size. Once or twice is believable- especially in the case of one particular character who talks about back pain and the like, but man, I swear, we couldn't get through this game without a female character saying something about their or another woman's chest. It was a little cringy, honestly, and a stain on an otherwise spectacular game. 

So yeah, the writing has its moments of weakness, but seriously, most of it's pretty fantastic. I really, really encourage you to pick up this game.

117882383.review:
Va-11 Hall-A is a cyberpunkish visual novel with a drink mixing minigame.

The game lasts for 19 days. Generally, each day goes like this. You go to work, bar owner and/or Gil (coworker) come in and talk to you for a little bit. Customer 1 comes in, talks to you, and orders 3 drinks that you make for them in a simple minigame. They leave, customer 2 comes in and repeat. After the 2nd customer, you go on break where you get to save the game. Come back from break and repeat the same exact process as the 1st half of the day. At the end of the day, you talk to Boss/Gil again, get your paycheck, and go home. At home, you can read some in-game web blogs, customize your apartment, and go out and purchase some random items that dress up your apartment and make Jill able to concentrate at work (which just means that she'll remind you what customers ordered rather than forcing you to memorize it). Occasionally, you'll need to have saved up enough money to pay some bill.

While I think the game is mostly fine, it has some issues that bog it down.

To begin, there's no real plot that goes anywhere. You start by learning that the bar is possibly going to get shutdown. This is mostly placed on the backburner and the plot becomes listen to people talk. The 2nd half of the game then abruptly shifts the plot to a personal issue that comes up for Jill... which then boils down to having people come in, talk to Jill, and try to cheer her up. This is very easily solved and then end of game.

The mixing drink mini-game is extremely easy and quickly becomes monotonous. Customer says what drink/type of drink they want, then you look up the drink on an in-game menu and add the ingredients. You can actually lose the game if you repeatedly make mistakes or make the same incorrect drink over and over again, but you pretty much have to intentionally do this. This offers the only real choices you'll make throughout the game as some drinks let you choose how much alcohol to add. This can get the customers drunk, which will change up the dialogue a bit. Somewhat notable and baffling is that the game completely fails during the tutorial to explain the difference between mixing and blending. This will be confusing for a few minutes until you figure it out or look it up.

The stories, characters, and writing are all a mixed bag. There's nothing notably horrible here but nothing notably good either. Sometimes the humor hits, other times it doesn't. Expect plenty of memes/sex/body related jokes/discussions. Sometimes the writing drags, other times it doesn't. Probably the biggest strength of this is that the characters all feel different from one another. Some characters you'll like and be happy to see pop in the bar, others you won't really care for one way or another. If a character you don't really care about comes in, you're going to be reading at length about them. Gil is mostly used as a punching bag throughout this.

The worst character throughout this might be the character you play as, Jill. She's struggling to make ends meet living in an apartment with a cat that she talks with. She smokes and is in love with her boss. The main issue with Jill is that she's kind of a coont. Despite her coontishness, everyone seems to like her an unreasonable amount. Beyond that, none of Jill's problems stem from anything other than the fact that she had the option of making smart choices or stupid choices, and intentionally chose to make stupid choices. Unless you're stupid as well, it's hard to sympathize with a character whose problems all stem from being dumb.

A minor but somewhat aggravating issue is that at the start of each day and each break, you select up to 12 songs on the jukebox to play while you're bartending. For whatever inexplicable reason, there's no random button.

Va-11 Hall-A is an above average visual novel. It's enjoyable enough on occasion, but it doesn't really do anything well enough to make it noteworthy and doesn't offer much to reflect on afterwards.

117111192.review:
Visual novel with player input limited to the creation of drinks for cyberpunk bar patrons. Fantastic characters, a lot of heart to the story. The cyberpunk world is familiar, but the very limited scope does wonders to give it a freshness. It's meandering in that slice-of-life kind of way; it has a lot of loose ends that suggest a bigger world rather than feeling unresolved. The grimdark brutality of hyper-capitalism, dehumanization, totalitarianism are all there, but instead of being the focus, they are the accents and accessories to the game's focus on people: jobs & careers, love & sex, regrets, ideas, friendships, and -- most refreshing of all -- small kindnesses. To be reductive, the Neuromancer cyberpunk is juxtaposed with bishojo sweetness to hit something touching and relatable, something greater than the sum of its parts.

Most of the dialogue is strong. Even at its weakest it rarely takes you out of the game, aside from a few egregious typos. Definitely horny, but not gratuitous. The social commentary and humor range from insightful to forgettable: Streamer-chan for example was an adequate send up of streamer culture on her first appearance. On her second, she was a worn-out bit. But the core cast -- Jill, Gillian, Boss, Alma, Dorothy, Sei and Stella -- are either deeply interesting or emotionally important to the others.

The art is pretty great, nostalgic but not bland; only gripe is a few of the characters (Gillian and Boss to be sure) could've stood to have more poses. Music is good, the meeting ground of chiptune and synthwave, though a few of the songs are a bit too punchy for such a slow-moving game.

The bartending mechanic was engaging for a single playthrough, though they didn't do much to progress or flesh out the repetitive task the way a game like Papers Please does. For the most part, I really enjoyed testing different drinks, remembering patron's favorites to build up friendship, finding secrets... all the hallmarks of a low-stakes vibe game. And some of the drinks have some dramatic weight behind them, like [spoiler]the drink to calm down Sei after the Bank Attack[/spoiler]. By the end, though, the drink making does feel like a tax to continue the scene. One or two drinks near the end still feel important, just wish there had been that last little bit of fine tuning to maintain momentum throughout.

Overall definitely worth the pickup if you're interested in lovely, relatable characters and a shifted perspective on worn-out cyberpunk tropes.

115849786.review:
To anyone thinking about buying the game I can only say: If you are interested in an authentic work of heart that manages to tell a great story for about 15 hours; this is your game. However, don't start the game with expectations for a AAA title that is filled to the brim with action, horror and heroism but rather with expectations for some 15 hours off chill time and thought-provoking topics of discussion.  

Having gone into the game with no previous experience with visual novels, I was not sure what to expect from the game.  
Especially the introduction was in some parts hard to follow. However, after being introduced to the core mechanic of mixing drinks and to the first few characters all of the setting became clear.  
Especially the beginning of the game can feel somewhat slow. However, after some time and the introduction of some more characters the game picks up on pace. 

There are some interesting anecdotes an situations in the game which give the game more depth which is great. Moreover, the game manages to balance between heartfelt moments of anger or despair and warm-hearted and funny scenes. Especially the second half of the game stirs your interest in the story and gets you more involved with the game. In addition to that, the last 3-5 hours of the game also manages to address serious topics such as grieve and feelings of guilt in a way that they seem relatable and realistic. 

In my opinion the game is great just how it is and I think it is a shame that we will likely not see a continuation of the story. 

Thank you for the great game Sukeban Games!

115273984.review:
★★★

VA-11 Hall-A  has the foundation to be one of the best VN experiences I have had the pleasure of playing, only coming just short of being such. Valhalla has an incredible atmosphere and roster of characters you interact with, its central mechanic is more or less a set dressing to the character interaction however there is something really personal about it. A lot of visual novel games I’ve played kind of reward pressing dialogue buttons with pieces of personal character information. “This is X’s favorite color”, and eventually you fill out a checklist about a character, without really knowing anything about them. In Valhalla you organically get these personally pieces about characters that you just know because of the drink mechanic, you know that Donovan’s always going to want a beer when he comes in, that a Piano Women will cheer Dorothy up if she’s sad, or that Alma’s favorite drink is a Brandtini. There’s no checklists in this game.

The only real shortcoming is that the capstone story moments needed just a bit more. A cutscene, a personal piece of dialogue, some kind of closure. I found myself a little unsatisfied with a lot of the important story moments because it felt as if they had ended abruptly, without properly closing out. Christmas in particular felt like the worst one, where before the party even really starts you take a smoke break with Alma and then it just ends. I think that for a game that has such a captivating cast of characters, and manages to circumvent a lot of the more egregious problems that VNs can run into where you don’t really get to know the characters you are interacting with, the pay-off for those in game relationships wasn’t substantial enough.

114568405.review:
This game is so good I bought it twice just to have it on steam.

First and foremost, the writing is brilliant. This isn't some overly dramatic story of blah blah. This is a peek into a very complete world, with characters that have motivations and flaws. The main character, Jill, is one of, if not the, best main character of a visual novel I’ve ever encountered. She’s relatable, yet very much an actor in her own life. You’ve just been given the opportunity to follow along. All other characters are fantastically written, whether it’s a recurring patron or a one-time-customer, they all are their own and are all charming in their own way. In addition, the game knows what it is and uses it to its advantage on multiple occasions. Let me phrase it like this: My favorite part of the game is simply having a beer with your boss.

Mechanically, you’re presented with a simple system for making a given drink by mixing ingredients. You’re generally told what to make, but given a lot of freedom to figure out which kind of drink and how much alcohol you’re giving out – which does have an effect on the following conversations. You’re also met with orders that act as riddles and others as questioning how well you know your customers. Additionally, when you return home, you’re tasked with balancing Jill’ whims and her duties. Along with the ability to read news, blogs and other gossip – which are all perfectly in sync with what’s happening in the bar.

Then there’s the soundtrack. I don’t know how to phrase this without sounding like a broken record, but it’s very, very good. You’re tasked with choosing the music for a given day, and therefore have a good time finding your favorite tracks and making your own personal playlist. They’re all “thematically similar” in fitting in within the game’ setting. But they’re far from similar in the typical sense.

Finally, I didn’t think much of the style to begin with – but being in it for hours made me really appreciate it. There’s a huge amount of time spent on the smallest details, and it shows in both subtle character emotions and the outright beautiful art.

If you’ve ever enjoyed any kind of visual novel, play this. You’ll regret it if you don’t.

If you haven’t, this is an excellent beginning.

If you don’t like reading, transhumanism/cyberpunk [b]and[/b] lbgt material – then this isn’t the game for you. Otherwise, at least give the game a try - VA-11 Hall-A is a great introduction to these themes without being drowned in it as many others do.

114317659.review:
I'm not usually one for visual novel-type games, but this one was a good one. It's probably one of the only visual novels that I've genuinely wanted to play ever since I've heard of it. Funny enough, I heard about the game from a collab with GFL, yet it took me another 3 or so years after to actually get around to buy the game and try it. 

After finally buying it and 100% completing it, I can say that the story is amazing. Like I said, visual novels usually bore me, just because I don't like the idea of the only action being to select different dialogue and stuff. This game balances the dialogue to match the gameplay, no matter how simple it is. I did accidentally spoil myself halfway through my first playthrough of the game, but I was able to find out about a secret drink, and how it brought new people to the bar. The small details in selecting different drinks (as well as spiking people's drinks with Karmotrine) kept me entertained. Top that off with a cyberpunk setting and retro-pixel graphics, and you've got an amazing game.

I do recommend buying it on sale though. Even if it is an amazing game, I probably wouldn't buy it at full price for around 12-15 hours of gameplay, unless you really like replaying visual novels. 

Once again, amazing game, and remember; optional Karmotrine = spike the drink.
